    Synthesis of 6-Amino- and 6-Arylazoazulenes via Nucleophilic Aromatic Substitution and Their Reactivity and Properties

    • Taku Shoji*
      Taku Shoji
      Graduate School of Science and Technology, Shinshu University, Matsumoto 390-8621, Japan
      *E-mail: tshoji@shinshu-u.ac.jp
      More by Taku Shoji
      http://orcid.org/0000-0001-8176-2389
      • , 
    • Shuhei Sugiyama
      Shuhei Sugiyama
      Graduate School of Science and Technology, Shinshu University, Matsumoto 390-8621, Japan

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    The nucleophilic aromatic substitution (SNAr) reaction of diethyl 6-bromoazulene-1,3-dicarboxylate (1) with a variety of amines afforded the corresponding 6-aminoazulene derivatives 2a–2j in good-to-excellent yields. 6-Aminoazulene derivatives 3a–3f without the 1,3-diethoxycarbonyl functions were obtained by the deesterification of 2a–2f with 100% H3PO4. The reactivity of 6-aminoazulenes toward the bromination, SNAr, and palladium-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions was also clarified. 6-Arylazoazulenes 13a–13c were also prepared via the SNAr reaction of 1 with arylhydrazines, followed by oxidation with Pb(OAc)4 in the presence of N2H4. The structural, optical, and electrochemical properties of the 6-amino- and 6-arylazoazulenes were revealed by single-crystal X-ray structure analysis, UV/vis spectroscopy, voltammetry analysis, spectroelectrochemistry, and theoretical calculations.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Aromatic amines are the very important component and/or precursor of pharmaceuticals (1) and organic electronic materials such as semiconductors, (2) solar cells, (3) light-emitting diodes, (4) and memory devices: (5) therefore, the various preparation and/or modification methods of such compounds have been developed so far. Ullmann reaction has often been adopted for the synthesis of arylamine derivatives as a method using a transition metal catalyst in the old days. (6) Whereas, Hartwig–Buchwald reaction is mainly applied as a current procedure, instead of the Ullmann reaction. (7) Aromatic nucleophilic substitution (SNAr) reaction of aryl halides with amines is one of the superior procedures for the arylamine synthesis as a method without the metal catalyst, despite the limited scope of the substrate and the high reaction temperature required. (8)
    Recently, efficient synthetic procedures for a variety of azulene derivatives have been developed for the applications to organic semiconductor, (9) photovoltaics, (10) and stimuli-responsive materials. (11) In the chemistry of azulene derivatives, amination reaction has also been developed to date. Ma̧kosza, Ostrowski, and their co-workers have reported two-types of synthetic procedure for 6-aminoazulene derivatives by the vicarious nucleophilic substitution reaction, but these procedures require liquid ammonia in the experimental manipulations (12) and generate 4-aminoazulene derivatives as a byproduct. (13) The SNAr reaction of 2-chloro- and 6-bromoazulenes is investigated by Nozoe et al. with several amines to afford the corresponding 2-amino- (14) and 6-aminoazulenes (15) in the early work, although there are problems concerning the amines applicable to the reaction and the products yield remained. To resolve the problems, we have recently reported an improved method for the preparation of 2-aminoazulene derivatives via the SNAr reaction, as well as the transformation to 2-arylazoazulenes. (16) As for the synthesis of 6-aminoazulene derivatives, we have demonstrated the Hartwig–Buchwald amination reaction with 6-bromoazulenes. (17) The method enabled the synthesis of 6-arylaminoazulenes that showed the reversible electrochromic behavior. However, the bulky phosphine ligand was indispensable in this reaction, and alkylamines have never been investigated as a nucleophile. For these reasons, the development of general and practical synthetic procedures for 6-aminoazulenes should contribute to the progress of pharmaceuticals and organic electronic materials containing the azulene unit.
    In this paper, we report the synthesis of 6-aminoazulenes by the SNAr reaction of the corresponding 6-bromoazulenes with a variety of amines, as well as the reactivity of 6-aminoazulenes. 6-Arylazoazulene derivatives were also prepared via the SNAr reaction of 6-bromoazulene derivatives with arylhydrazines, followed by the oxidation with Pb(OAc)4 in the presence of N2H4. The structure of several products was clarified by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The optical and electrochemical properties of the 6-amino- and 6-arylazoazulene derivatives were clarified by UV/vis spectroscopy, voltammetry analysis, spectroelectrochemistry, and theoretical calculations.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Synthesis and Reactivity of 6-Aminoazulenes

    In the early years of azulene chemistry, as described above, Nozoe et al. have reported the synthesis of 6-aminoazulenes by the SNAr reaction of 6-bromoazulenes with several amines. (10) However, the yield of the products under the reported conditions was relatively low, when the reaction was carried out in refluxing ethanol. Thus, the successful condition for 2-aminoazulene synthesis that we have reported in recent years (11) (i.e., the reaction of haloazulenes with a variety of amines without solvent) was adapted to the synthesis of 6-aminoazulenes.
    Indeed, the reaction of diethyl 6-bromoazulene-1,3-dicarboxylate (1) with a variety of amines gave 6-aminoazulene derivatives 2a–2j in moderate-to-excellent yields (50–97%) as shown in Table 1. For instance, 6-aminoazulene derivative 2c with morpholine function was obtained in 33% yield, when the SNAr reaction was performed under the conditions reported in the literature. (10) Whereas, the product 2c was obtained in much higher yield (94%, entry 3). Other known compounds 2a (95%), 2b (96%), and 2f (93%) were also prepared in the yields superior to the results described in the literature (entries 1, 2, and 7). The SNAr reaction generally proceeded with primary and secondary amines under the identical conditions to give the corresponding 6-aminoazulene derivatives in excellent yields, but the slight decrease in the yield was observed in the reaction with n-butylamine (71%) and tert-butylamine (50%), which might be due to the lower reaction temperature arising from the lower boiling point of the amines. When the low boiling point amines (under 100 °C) were employed, the excess amines used in the reaction could be recovered by the simple evaporation protocol without the precise distillation because of the absence of any other volatile materials used for the reaction.
    Table 1. Synthesis of 6-Aminoazulenes 2a–2j by SNAr Reaction of 6-Bromoazulene 1 with Amines and Their Deesterification into 3a–3f
    a

    Reaction was carried out at 80 °C.

    b

    Reaction was performed at reflux temperature.

    c

    Isolated yield.

    Deesterification of 6-aminoazulenes 2a–2j by employing 100% H3PO4 was also examined in order to transform 2a–2j into the 6-aminoazulenes without the 1,3-diethoxycarbonyl functions. (18) The deesterification of the 2-aminoazulenes required the high reaction temperature (150 °C) due to the deactivation by the intramolecular hydrogen bonding between the 2-amino group and the 1,3-diethoxycarbonyl functions. (11) However, the deesterification of the 6-aminoazulene derivatives proceeded at much lower temperatures because of the lack of intramolecular hydrogen bonding. The 6-aminoazulenes 2a–2f obtained by the reaction with secondary amines smoothly reacted to give the deesterified products 3a–3f in excellent yields, when the 6-aminoazulenes 2a–2f were heated at 90 °C in 100% H3PO4 (Table 1). Since the 1,3-positions of the azulene ring are the most reactive sites toward electrophiles, further functionalization could be established by the electrophilic substitution of 6-aminoazulenes 3a–3f obtained by the reaction. Whereas, decomposition of the compounds was observed in the reaction of 2g–2j obtained by the reaction with primary amines, likewise were the results on the deesterification of 2-aminoazulene derivatives. (11)
    Preparation of 2-haloazulene derivatives is usually difficult and required the multistep process. (9,19) Recently, Murafuji and his colleagues reported the two-step synthesis of 2-iodoazulene from parent azulene via the borylation at the 2-position. (20) Although this synthetic strategy is an innovative and efficient method that can introduce the iodo function directly into parent azulene to give 2-iodoazulene, an expensive iridium-catalyst must be used in the borylation process at the 2-position of azulene ring. As a simpler and economical synthetic method for 2-haloazulenes, Yasunami and Suzuka have previously reported the reaction of 2a with Br2 to afford 2-bromoazulene 4. (21) Despite the fact that the method is effective for the preparation of 2-bromoazulene 4, bromination of the other 6-aminoazulenes have not been explored so far. Therefore, to verify the versatility and reproducibility of the bromination reaction, 6-aminoazulenes 2a–2c were conducted under the reaction conditions as described in the literature.
    As a first examination, we reconstructed the bromination of 2a with Br2 under the conditions described in the literature (Scheme 1). Indeed, we confirmed the reproducibility of the reaction, which proceeded selectively at the 2-position of azulene ring to give product 4 in 78% yield. On the other hand, the reaction of 6-aminoazulenes 2b and 2c with Br2 afforded the products 5 (54%) and 6 (52%), respectively, in which the bromination at the 5- and/or 7-positions of the azulene ring has also taken place in addition to that at the 2-position (Scheme 1). These differences in the reactivity could be explained by the difference in the solubility of the brominated products 2a–2c under the reaction conditions; the monobromination product 4 precipitated in the progress of the reaction of 2a but in the case of the reaction products for 2b and 2c did not show any precipitation until the polybrominated products 5 and 6 were formed. In the early years of azulene chemistry, Anderson Jr. and Replogle reported the preparation of 1,3,5-tribromoazulene by the reaction of 1,3-dibromoazulene with N-bromosuccinimide. (22) In 2009, Nielsen et al. also demonstrated the stepwise synthesis of 5-bromoazulene derivative by E2 elimination of dihydroazulene derivative with bromine substituents. (23) However, bromination of azulenes at the 5- and/or 7-positions is still difficult even today because of the scarcity of an effective preparation method. Therefore, this strategy should become one of the useful bromination methods for the 5- and/or 7-positions of the azulene ring, although the amino function at the 6-position is necessitated to promote the reaction.
    To clarify the reactivity of the brominated product, 2-bromo-6-pyrrolidinylazulene 4, the SNAr and palladium-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions were examined (Scheme 2). The SNAr reaction of 4 with pyrrolidine at the reflux temperature afforded 2,6-dipyrrolidinylazulene 7 in 98% yield. Previously, we have reported the synthesis of 2,6-diaminoazulene derivatives by the SNAr reaction of diethyl 2-amino-6-bromoazulene-1,3-dicarboxylate with some cyclic amines, but the synthesis required high reaction temperature (i.e., 130 °C), in order to complete the reaction. (24) The lower temperature in the reaction of 4 indicates the higher reactivity toward the SNAr reaction at the 2-position of azulene ring rather than that at the 6-position. Furthermore, the bromination of 7 with Br2 gave 8 with a bromine substituent at the 5-position in 75% yield as a sole product.
    Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling of 4 with phenylboronic acid by employing 3 mol % [Pd(PPh3)4] catalyst and K2CO3 as a base and subsequent chromatographic purification on silica gel afforded 2-phenyl-6-pyrrolidinylazulene 9 in 97% yield. Although Sonogashira–Hagihara cross-coupling of 4 with ethynylbenzene in the presence of 3 mol % Pd-catalyst and 10 mol % CuI produced the cross-coupling product 10 in low yield (12%) along with the recovery of 4 (85%), the use of excess CuI (50 mol %) has shown a significant improvement of the yield of 10 (89%). These results suggest the coordination of CuI to the pyrrolidine moiety in 4 that leads to a decrease in the activity of the Cu-catalyst because 2-haloazulenes without the 6-amino substituent give the products in good-to-excellent yields in the presence of catalytic amount of CuI. (25)
    To evaluate the reactivity of the alkyne moiety of 10, transformation to the tetracyanobutadiene (TCBD) derivative was investigated by the [2 + 2] cycloaddition–retroelectrocyclization (CA–RE) with tetracyanoethylene (TCNE). It is well-known that alkyne derivatives without an electron-donating group do not react with TCNE. (26) Previously, we have also reported that the reaction of 2-ethynyl- and 2-phenylethynylazulenes with TCNE did not afford the corresponding TCBD derivative, since the 2-azulenyl moiety is an unfavorable activating group toward the [2 + 2] CA–RE reaction. (18) Contrary to these results, compound 10 reacted with TCNE at room temperature to afford the corresponding TCBD derivative 11 in 94% yield, despite the deactivation of the alkyne moiety by the adjacent two electron-withdrawing groups. Generation of 11 in high yield under the mild condition should be attributed to the strong electron-donating property of the pyrrolidinyl group at the 6-position that enhances the reactivity of the alkyne moiety of 10.

    Spectroscopic Properties of 6-Aminoazulenes

    6-Aminoazulene derivatives prepared by this work were fully characterized on the basis of their spectral data as summarized in the Experimental Section. High-resolution mass spectra (HRMS) of the new compounds ionized by FAB showed the correct molecular ion peaks. Since the single crystals were obtained from the slow evaporation of CH2Cl2/MeOH mixed solvent, the molecular structure of 5 and 9 was clarified by single-crystal X-ray structure analysis (Figures 1 and 2). The X-ray crystal structure analysis proved the existence of two bromine substituents on 5 (Figure 1). In the crystal structure, the benzene ring in 9 showed the geometry perpendicular to the azulene ring with a dihedral angle of 85.9(0)° owing to the steric hindrance by the two ester groups substituted at the 1,3-positions (Figure 2). From this fact, it is concluded that the phenyl group scarcely contributes to the extension of the π-conjugated system in 9.
    The UV/vis spectra of 6-pyrrolidinylazulene derivatives 2a, 7, and 9–11 in CH2Cl2 are shown in Figure 3. The absorption maxima (λmax) and their molar extinction coefficients (log ε) of 2a, 7, and 9–11 are summarized in Table 2. The maximum absorption wavelength of 2a, 7, and 9–11 was depending on the substituent at the 2-position as observed in their UV/vis spectra.
    Table 2. Absorption Maxima (λmax) and Their Coefficients (log ε) in the Visible Region of 2a, 7, and 9–11 in CH2Cl2 and Their Electronic Transitions Derived from the Computed Values Based on the TD–DFT Calculations at the B3LYP/6-311G* Levela
     experimentalcomputed values
    sampleλmax (log ε)λmax (strength)composition of band (amplitude)H–L gap (eV)
    2a425 (3.80)425 (0.0002)H–1 → L + 1 (0.3329)3.82
       H → L (0.9401) 
    7466 (4.37)451 (0.0270)H–1 → L (0.4256)3.26
       H → L + 1 (0.8894) 
     439 sh (4.27)416 (0.2121)H → L (0.8934) 
      390 (0.0182)H–2 → L + 1 (0.2969) 
       H–1 → L (0.8650) 
    9430 sh (3.98)423 (0.0005)H → L (0.9394)3.83
     397 (4.50)   
    10426 (4.72)442 (0.0006)H–1 → L (0.8846)3.28
      392 (0.8281)H–1 → L + 1 (0.4205) 
       H → L (0.8907) 
    11593 sh (3.43)598 (0.0012)H → L (0.9955)2.75
     532 (3.62)538 (0.0341)H–1 → L (0.9804) 
     392 (4.49)421 (0.0045)H → L + 1 (0.9313) 
      414 (0.0026)H–3 → L (0.9757) 
      412 (0.0868)H–4 → L (0.5039) 
       H–2 → L (0.8085) 
    a

    sh = shoulder peak; H = HOMO, L = LUMO; The computed values were calculated in vacuum.

    6-Pyrrolidinylazulene 2a in CH2Cl2 displayed a strong absorption band at λmax = 389 nm and weak broad absorption band at λmax = 425 nm in the visible region. Compound 9 with 2-phenyl substituent also exhibited similar absorption bands at λmax = 397 and 430 (sh) nm, which showed the slight bathochromic shift by 8 and 5 nm, respectively, compared with those of 2a. These results are attributable to the low planarity between azulene and benzene rings in 9 as observed by single-crystal X-ray structure analysis to prevent the effective π-conjugation that should lead to the bathochromic shift in the absorption bands (Figure 3). The maximum absorption wavelengths of 7 (λmax = 439 sh and 466 nm) having two pyrrolidinyl groups showed the red-shift compared with those of 2a and 9. A strong absorption band was observed in the absorption spectrum of 10 (λmax = 426 nm) probably due to the ICT nature between the substituted ethynyl and amino moieties. In the case of TCBD 11, a broad absorption band at λmax = 532 nm, which is a typical ICT band for the azulene-substituted TCBDs, (23) appeared in the UV/vis spectrum, along with the strong absorption band at λmax = 392 nm.
    To elucidate the origin of the absorption bands in the visible region of 2a, 7, and 9–11, theoretical calculations were performed using the time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) at the B3LYP/6-311G* level. (28) The frontier Kohn–Sham orbitals and their energy levels are summarized in the Supporting Information.
    Theoretical calculations disclosed that the longest wavelength absorption band of 6-pyrrolidynylazulene derivatives 2a, 7, 9, and 10 was derived from the transition from HOMO and HOMO – 1 to LUMO and LUMO + 1, that is the π–π* transition of the azulene ring itself (see the Supporting Information). However, the energy levels for HOMO and LUMO of these compounds significantly depended on the substituent at the 2-position of the azulene ring. The energy levels of HOMO (−5.59 eV) and LUMO (−1.77 eV) of 2a were almost the same as those of 9 (HOMO = −5.60 eV, LUMO = −1.77 eV). These results imply that the phenyl group on 9 does not contribute to the π-extension, due to the low planarity of the molecule by the orthogonally arranged phenyl group to the azulene ring as represented by both single-crystal X-ray structure analysis and UV/vis spectral measurement. On the other hand, the HOMO–LUMO gap of 10 (3.28 eV) showed a smaller value than that of 2a (3.82 eV) and 9 (3.83 eV), according to the effective π-conjugation between the azulene and phenylethynyl moieties. Compound 7 bearing pyrrolidinyl groups at the 2- and 6-positions showed the highest HOMO energy level (−4.80 eV) among the calculated compounds because of the two electron-donating groups substituted on the azulene ring, but the LUMO level (−1.54 eV) was not raised so much, resulting in the small HOMO–LUMO gap showing a red-shift of the maximum absorption wavelength in 7. In the case of TCBD derivative 11 that has the lowest HOMO (−6.19 eV) and LUMO (−3.44 eV) levels, the longest wavelength absorption band was originated from the transition from the HOMO and HOMO – 1, which was mainly located on the azulene ring, and the LUMO, which was located on the TCBD moiety. Thus, the absorption band at λmax = 532 nm could be assignable to the CT absorption between azulene and TCBD moieties.

    Electrochemical Properties of 6-Aminoazulenes

    To investigate the effect of the substituent on the azulene ring at the 2-position on the electrochemical properties, the redox behavior of 6-pyrrolidinylazulene 2a and 2,6-disubstituted azulenes 7 and 9–11 was examined by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) experiments (Table 3).
    Table 3. Redox Potentialsa of 6-Pyrrolidinylazulene 2a and 2,6-Disubstituted Azulenes 7 and 9–11
    samplemethodE1ox (V)E2ox (V)E3ox (V)E1red (V)E2red (V)
    2a(DPV)(+0.82)––––
    7CVb+0.10––––
     (DPV)(+0.08)(+0.59)(+1.06)––
    9(DPV)(+0.74)––––
    10(DPV)(+0.70)(+0.88)–––
    11CVb––––0.64–1.19
     (DPV)(+1.11)(+1.42)–(−0.62)(−1.17)
    a

    1 mM in benzonitrile containing Et4NClO4 (0.1 M), Pt electrode (internal diameter: 1.6 mm), scan rate = 100 mVs–1 (CV) and 20 mVs–1 (DPV), and external standard Fc/Fc+ = +0.15 V.

    b

    Half-wave potentials Ered = (Epc + Epa)/2 on CV.

    The oxidation potential of 2a, 7, and 9–11 was varied clearly by the substituent at the 2-position of the azulene ring. The first oxidation potential of 10 (E1ox = +0.70 V) with a phenylethynyl moiety on DPV exhibited a cathodic shift compared to those of 2a (E1ox = +0.82 V) and 9 (E1ox = +0.74 V) due to the decrease in the HOMO level as expected by the DFT calculations. Compound 7 with two pyrrolidinyl groups represented a quasi-reversible oxidation wave at E1ox = +0.10 V (Figure 4), which was the lowest oxidation potential among that of 2a, 7, and 9–11. The low potential of 7 could be explained by the presumed redox behavior represented in Scheme 3, which constructs Wurster-type redox system like that of p-phenylenediamine derivatives. (29) The first oxidation wave of 7 is attributable to the formation of radical cation 7•+ by the electrochemical oxidation, which is stabilized by the delocalization of the radical cation via the resonance form such as 7′•+. (12) On the other hand, the irreversibility in the second oxidation wave should be explained by the instability of the dicationic species 72+.
    In contrast, 11 having an electron-withdrawing TCBD group at the 2-position on azulene ring showed the highest oxidation potential (E1ox = +1.11 V) on DPV. In consequence, the electronic nature of the substituent on the azulene ring at the 2-position clearly influenced to the HOMO level of these compounds, as predicted from the results on the theoretical calculations.
    In the region of the potential window of benzonitrile, compounds 2a, 7, 9, and 10 did not show any distinct peaks under the reduction conditions by CV and DPV, probably resulting from the increase in the LUMO-level derived from the electron-donating nature of the pyrrolidinyl group at the 6-position on azulene ring. On the other hand, TCBD derivative 11 denoted two quasi-reversible reduction waves (E1red = −0.64 V, E2red = −1.19 V) on CV because of the generation of dianionic species by the stepwise electrochemical reduction of the TCBD moiety (Figure 5).
    Electrochromism is the phenomenon that observed in reversible redox molecules that display the significant color changes in different redox states. (30) Since compounds 7 and 11 showed reversible redox behavior in CV measurements, these derivatives should act as electrochromic molecules despite their relatively simple structure. Therefore, the visible spectral changes of 7 and 11 were monitored by spectroelectrochemical measurements to identify their electrochromic behavior during the redox reactions.
    When the spectral changes of 7 were measured under the electrochemical oxidation conditions, the generation of new peaks at λmax = 510 and 730 nm was observed along with the disappearance of the absorption band at around 470 nm (Figure 6, left). The spectral changes should be attributed to the generation of the radical cationic species formed by the electrochemical oxidation of 7. Reverse reduction of the oxidized species of 7 recovered the original spectrum of 7 (Figure 6, right).
    Electrochemical reduction at −0.90 V of 11 exhibited the development of a broad absorption band over the entire whole visible region (Figure 7, left), and further reduction at −1.50 V exhibited a decrement of the extinction coefficient at around 550 nm along with the development of an absorption band in the near-infrared region (Figure 7, right). Reverse oxidation of the reduced species of 11 denoted the stepwise recovery of the original spectrum of 11 but incompletely (Figure 8).

    Synthesis of 6-Arylazoazulenes

    Azoarene derivatives have been applied to organic functional materials such as super- and semiconductors, (31) liquid crystals, (32) magnetic, (33) and energy storage materials. (34) Furthermore, azo compounds have recently fascinated attention in chemical biology and medicinal chemistry. (35) Therefore, various azoarene derivatives have been prepared so far. In the azulene chemistry, the preparation and properties of 1-arylazo- and 2-arylazoazulenes have been reported by Razus et al. (36) and our group, (11) toward the application to organic electronics and functional dyes. 2-Arylazoazulene derivatives were expected to show both the bathochromic shift in the longest wavelength absorption band and the increment of the molar extinction coefficient based on the extension of π-conjugation, but the low planarity between the azulene and arylazo moieties in the 2-arylazoazulene derivatives counteracted the effects. Since the properties of the azulene derivative significantly depend on the substitution position of the function on azulene ring, 6-arylazoazulene derivatives should exhibit the characteristic optical and electrochemical properties by comparison with those of 2-arylazoazulenes. Therefore, we examined the synthesis of 6-arylazoazulenes via the SNAr reaction, as well as their optical and electrochemical properties.
    Likewise as the synthesis of 2-arylazoazulene derivatives, preparation of 6-arylazoazulenes was accomplished by the SNAr reaction of 1 with four arylhydrazines, followed by the treatment with Pb(OAc)4 as an oxidant (Scheme 4). Although the reaction of 1 with arylhydrazines afforded the corresponding 6-azulenylhydrazines 12a–12d, these hydrazine intermediates were unstable and readily decomposed in the purification process as similar with 2-azulenylhydrazines. (11) Therefore, the crude products 12a–12d were oxidized with Pb(OAc)4 in the presence of 80% hydrazine to afford 6-arylazoazulenes 13a–13c in excellent yields (84–90%), except for 13d (2%). The low yield of 13d should be attributed to the instability of the compound under the oxidation condition probably due to the p-methoxyphenyl moiety with a higher HOMO level. Although the oxidation of 12a–12d without 80% hydrazine was also examined, the compounds completely decomposed under the reaction conditions. Therefore, 80% hydrazine might contribute to reducing the oxidizing ability of Pb(OAc)4.
    Conversion of 13a–13c into the 6-arylazoazulenes without the 1,3-diethoxycarbonyl functions was also examined for better understanding of the nature of these derivatives. When 13b and 13c were treated with 100% H3PO4 at 90 °C, these compounds led to the decomposition instead of the generation of the deesterified products. On the other hand, in the case of the reaction of 13a, deesterification was established to give 6-arylazoazulene (14), but in low yield (12%), along with significant decomposition of the compound.

    Properties of 6-Arylazoazulenes

    The new 6-arylazoazulenes were fully characterized on the basis of their spectral data, as summarized in the Experimental Section. The HRMS of these derivatives ionized by MALDI showed the expected molecular ion peaks. These results show the correctness of the structure of the new products. The molecular structure of 13b and 14 was clarified by single-crystal X-ray structure analysis (Figures 9 and 10) because suitable single crystals for the analysis were obtained from the mixed solvent of CH2Cl2/MeOH. Since the compound 13b precipitated as polymorphs (plate and needle), structural analysis was performed on both crystals. 2-Arylazoazulenes 15a–15c (Figure 12) have previously been revealed as having twisted structures about the arylazo group to the azulene ring owing to the steric hindrance by the two ester groups substituted at the 1,3-positions. (14) Whereas, the arylazo moiety and azulene ring in 13b and 14 showed the planarity in their crystal structure. The X-ray structure analysis revealed that the dihedral angle between the aryl and azulenyl groups of 13b and 14 was 20.0(3)° and 4.0(5)°, respectively.
    The UV/vis spectra of 13a–13c and 14 in CH2Cl2 are shown in Figure 11. The absorption maxima (λmax) and their molar extinction coefficients (log ε) of 13a–13c and 14 are summarized in Table 4. 6-Arylazoazulenes 13a–13c with two ester functions displayed a strong absorption band at around 390 nm and a broad absorption band at 470–490 nm in their UV/vis spectra. The maximum absorption wavelength of 6-arylazoazulenes 13a–13c in these regions represented the red-shift compared to those of the corresponding 2-arylazoazulenes 15a–15c (15a: 458 nm; 15b: 462 sh nm; 15c: 455 nm) (see Figure 12). (11) These results suggest the effective extension of the π-conjugated system by the arylazo group with the highly planar structure to the azulene ring in 13a–13c. The weak absorption band at around 590 nm, which might attribute to the π–π* transition of azulene ring itself, was also observed as a shoulder peak in the UV/vis spectrum of 13a–13c, although the 6-aminoazulene derivatives did not exhibit the absorption band in this region. However, there are little differences in the maximum absorption wavelength among the three derivatives. This fact means that the transition energy of 13a–13c is not significantly affected by the para-substituents on the benzene ring at the arylazo moiety. The maximum absorption wavelength of 14 (λmax = 658 nm) showed a red-shift by about 60–80 nm compared with those of 13a–13c.
    Table 4. Absorption Maxima (λmax) and Their Coefficients (log ε) in the Visible Region of 6-Arylazoazulenes 13a–13c and 14 in CH2Cl2 and Their Electronic Transitions Derived from the Computed Values Based on the TD–DFT Calculations at the B3LYP/6-31G** Levela
     experimentalcomputed values
    sampleλmax (log ε)λmax (strength)composition of band (amplitude)H–L gap (eV)
    13a592 sh (2.93)584 (0.0087)H → L (0.9737)2.74
     466 (3.36)536 (0.0009)H–2 → L (0.9576) 
     493 sh (3.33) H–1 → L (0.2286) 
     396 sh (4.24)373 (0.7117)H–1 → L (0.8720) 
    13b584 sh (3.01)579 (0.0088)H → L (0.9730)2.76
     489 sh (3.27)535 (0.0012)H–2 → L (0.9683) 
     398 sh (4.40)378 (1.0170)H–1 → L (0.9157) 
       H → L + 1 (0.2831) 
    13c597 sh (2.93)596 (0.0087)H → L (0.9749)2.68
     477 (3.20)531 (0.0011)H–2 → L (0.9742) 
     398 sh (4.35)381 (1.0071)H–1 → L (0.9193) 
    14658 (2.66)636 (0.0119)H → L (0.9759)2.54
     471 sh (3.05)525 (0.0006)H–2 → L (0.9800) 
     390 (4.22)379 (0.5837)H–1 → L (0.8472) 
       H → L + 1 (0.4873) 
    a

    sh = shoulder peak; H = HOMO, L = LUMO; The computed values were calculated in vacuum.

    To examine the theoretical aspects of the spectroscopic properties, molecular orbital calculations were performed on 13a–13c and 14 using TD-DFT at the B3LYP/6-31G** level. The frontier Kohn–Sham orbitals of 13a–13c and 14 are shown in the Supporting Information. The calculations showed that the longest wavelength absorption band at around 590 nm of 13a–13c and 14 is caused by the transition from the HOMO to the LUMO (i.e., the π–π* transition of the azulene ring itself). Although there are some differences in the HOMO and LUMO energy levels in 13a–13c, these compounds show almost the same HOMO–LUMO energy gaps that reflect the absorption band in a similar wavelength region in their UV/vis spectra. The theoretical calculation revealed that the bathochromic shift of the absorption wavelength of the deesterified product 14 is derived from the smaller HOMO–LUMO energy gap compared with those of 13a–13c. The calculations also clarified that the absorption band at the shorter wavelength region of 13a–13c and 14 arose from the transition between the azulene and arylazo moieties.
    The redox potentials (in volts vs Ag/Ag+) of 6-arylazoazulenes 13a–13c and 14, as well as those of 2-arylazoazulenes 15a–15c, (11) measured by CV and DPV methods are summarized in Table 5. The CV and DPV experiments clarified the dependence on the electronic nature of the para-substituents on the arylazo moiety in the redox potentials.
    Table 5. Redox Potentialsa of 6-Arylazoazulenes 13a–13c and 14, and Those of 2-Arylazoazulenes 15a–15c as Reference Compounds
    samplemethodE1ox (V)E2ox (V)E1red (V)E2red (V)E1ox – E1red (V)
    13aCVb–––0.93– 
     (DPV)(+1.30)(+1.60)(−0.91)(−1.26)2.21
    13bCVb–––0.96– 
     (DPV)(+1.28)(+1.53)(−0.94)(−1.33)2.22
    13cCVb–––0.88– 
     (DPV)(+1.34)(+1.66)(−0.86)(−1.21)2.20
    14CVb–––1.18– 
     (DPV)(+0.80)–(−1.16)(−1.44)1.96
    15a11(DPV)(+1.30)–(−1.18)–2.48
    15b11(DPV)(+1.26)–(−1.21)(−1.66)2.47
    15c11(DPV)(+1.31)–(−1.14)(−1.54)2.45
    a

    1 mM in benzonitrile containing Et4NClO4 (0.1 M), Pt electrode (internal diameter: 1.6 mm), scan rate = 100 mVs–1 (CV) and 20 mVs–1 (DPV), and external standard Fc/Fc+ = +0.15 V.

    b

    Half-wave potentials Ered = (Epc + Epa)/2 on CV.

    The electrochemical reduction of 6-arylazoazulenes 13a–13c exhibited quasi-reversible redox waves on the CV, although that of 2-arylazoazulenes 15a–15c was expressed by the low reversibility (Figure 13). The redox behavior of 13a–13c could be explained as illustrated in Scheme 5. When the azo moiety in 13a–13c is electrochemically reduced, stabilized radical anions 13a•––13c•– should be formed. The delocalization of the radical anions, such as cyclopentadienide anions 13a′•––13c′•–, could be expected by the resonance effect between azulene ring connected. Therefore, redox wave of 6-arylazoazulenes 13a–13c should exhibit the higher reversibility on CV than that of 2-arylazoazulenes 15a–15c which are not expected such a stabilizing effect.
    Compound 13b (E1red = −0.96 V) with an electron-donating methyl group on the benzene ring at the para-position showed cathodic shift of the first reduction potential compared to that of 13a (E1red = −0.93 V), while that of 13c (E1red = −0.88 V) having an electron-withdrawing chloro group exhibited anodic shit of the potential. The deesterified product 14 (E1red = −1.18 V) showed a cathodic shift in the first reduction potential relative to those of 13a–13c, which should be attributed to the increase in the LUMO-level by the removal of the two ester functions at the 1,3-positions. The first oxidation potential of 13b (E1ox = +1.28 V) measured by DPV was slightly decreased relative to that of 13a (E1ox = +1.30 V), whereas the opposite phenomenon was observed in 13c, that is, an anodic shift in the first oxidation potential (E1ox = +1.34 V). The deesterified product 14 (E1ox = +0.80 V) showed the lowest oxidation potential among the 6-arylazoazulenes prepared. These differences in the redox potentials of 6-arylazoazulenes indicate that the HOMO and LUMO energy levels are directly affected by the substituents on both the azulene and benzene rings.
    Similar with 2-arylazoazulenes 15a–15c, 6-arylazoazulenes 13a–13c showed almost the same electrochemical energy gap (E1ox – E1red) within the derivatives as predicted by the results on the UV/vis spectral measurements and theoretical calculations. However, the energy gap of 13a–13c was smaller than that of the corresponding 2-arylazoazulenes 15a–15c. These differences should be ascribed by the discrepancy in the structure between 13a–13c and 15a–15c; arylazo and azulene moieties in 13a–13c showed high planarity as observed by the single-crystal X-ray structure analysis, but 15a–15c are revealed as the twisted structure. The high planarity leads to decrease in the HOMO–LUMO energy gaps resulting from the effective expansion of the π-conjugated system. Moreover, the first oxidation potential of 6-arylazoazulenes 13a–13c with two ester functions displayed an anodic shift, compared with that of 6-pyrrolidinylazulene derivatives 2a, 7, 9, and 10. These differences could be explained by the effect of the substituent at the 6-position of the azulene ring; since the azo group acts as an electron-withdrawing group to decrease the HOMO level that causes the anodic shift of the oxidation potential. In contrast, the pyrrolidinyl group, an electron-donating group, induces a cathodic shift of the first oxidation potential owing to the increase in the HOMO level. Indeed, the apparent differences in the HOMO level between 6-pyrrolidinyl and 6-arylazoazulene derivatives were reproduced by the DFT calculations (see Figures S135–S143).
    The photochromic behavior of 6-arylazoazulenes 13a–13c and 14 with the arylazo moiety was examined by the photo irradiation conditions. However, decomposition of the compounds was only observed under the irradiation with ultraviolet light at 254 nm, and no isomerization was also observed under the light-irradiation at 365 nm. These results should be attributed to the overlap of the absorption bands of azulene and arylazo moieties. Whereas, electrochromism of 13a–13c and 14 was revealed by the spectroelectrochemical measurements under the electrochemical reduction conditions. The electrochromic behavior of 13a–13c closely resembled each other reflecting their similar electronic nature (see the Supporting Information). For example, the spectral change of 13a was attendant on the development of a new absorption band at around 520 nm owing to the generation of a radical anionic species, when the spectra were monitored under the electrochemical reduction conditions (Figure 14, left). In contrast, the electrochemical reduction of 14 at −1.40 V showed the increment of an absorption band at around 550 nm, which was spreading into the near-infrared region (Figure 15, left). Reverse oxidation of these reduced species exhibited the recovery of the original spectra of 13a and 14 that suggested a high stability of the radical anionic species formed from 13a and 14 as observed by CV experiments (Figures 14 and 15, right), although the clear isosbestic point was not observed in these cases.

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In conclusion, we have described herein an efficient and practical procedure for the synthesis of 6-aminoazulene derivatives by the SNAr reaction with a variety of amines. 6-Bromoazulene 1 with two ester functions at the 1,3-positions reacted with primary and secondary amines to afford 6-aminoazulene derivatives 2a–2j in good-to-excellent yields. Although the SNAr reaction of 1 with arylamines was not investigated in this study, the project is currently underway in our laboratory.
    The deesterification of 2a–2f with 100% H3PO4 proceeded smoothly to give the corresponding 6-aminoazulenes 3a–3f without the 1,3-diethoxycarbonyl functions, while the similar reaction of 2h–2j resulted in decomposition of the compounds. In the bromination reaction of 2a–2c, the different number of bromine atoms was able to be introduced to give the products 4–6 depending on the solubility of the brominated products. To further transform 4, several reactions including the SNAr and the palladium-catalyzed cross-coupling were investigated.
    The SNAr reaction was also applied to the preparation of 6-arylazoazulenes. The reaction of 1 with three arylhydrazines gave unstable azulenylhydrazine intermediates, which were transformed into 6-arylazoazulenes 13a–13c by the treatment with Pb(OAc)4 in the presence of N2H4. Within the 6-arylazoazulenes 13a–13c, only 13a gave the deesterified product 14 by the reaction with 100% H3PO4, but in low yield.
    The structural, optical and electrochemical properties of the new 6-amino- and 6-arylazoazulenes obtained by these reactions were investigated by single-crystal X-ray structure analysis, UV/vis spectroscopy, voltammetry analysis, and theoretical calculations. These results suggest that the substituent on the azulene ring and its substitution position greatly influence their properties. We anticipate that the results represented herein should afford an effective preparation method for the novel azulene derivatives that are difficult to obtain and should contribute to the development of pharmaceuticals and organic electronic materials including an azulene skeleton.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    General Methods

    1H and 13C NMR spectra were measured at 500 MHz (1H NMR) and 125 MHz (13C NMR), respectively. Voltammetry measurements were carried out in benzonitrile as a measurement solvent, with Pt working and auxiliary electrodes and a reference electrode formed from Ag/AgNO3 (0.01 M) in acetonitrile-containing tetrabutylammonium perchlorate (0.1 M).

    Compound 2a

    A solution of 1 (703 mg, 2.00 mmol) in pyrrolidine (15 mL) was stirred at 80 °C for 1 h. After the reaction mixture was cooled, the amine was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography with CH2Cl2/EtOAc (20:1) as the eluent to afford 2a (649 mg, 95%) as orange crystals. Mp: 203–204 °C (Lit. 194–195 °C, decomp.); (10) IR (AT-IR): νmax = 2985 (w, C–H), 2874 (w, C–H), 1667 (s, C = O) cm –1; UV/vis (CH 2Cl2): λmax = 259 (4.21), 276 (4.12), 287 (4.19), 348 (4.75), 375 sh (4.40), 389 (4.34), 425 (3.80) nm; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.25 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H4,8), 8.23 (s, 1H, H2), 6.68 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H5,7), 4.37 (q, 4H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 3.49 (t, 4H, J = 6.4 Hz, pyrrolidine), 2.10–2.07 (m, 4H, J = 6.4 Hz, pyrrolidine), 1.41 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 165.9, 157.7, 138.3, 135.5, 134.6, 115.2, 115.0, 59.5, 49.5, 25.5, 14.8 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C20H24NO4, 342.1700; found, 342.1679.

    Compound 2b

    A solution of 1 (178 mg, 0.51 mmol) in piperidine (10 mL) was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h. After the reaction mixture was cooled, the amine was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography with CH2Cl2/EtOAc (50:1) as the eluent to afford 2b (173 mg, 96%) as orange crystals. Mp: 153–154 °C (Lit. 103.0–103.5 °C); (10) IR (AT-IR): νmax = 2981 (w, C–H), 2945 (w, C–H), 1685 (m, C = O) cm –1; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.32 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H4,8), 8.29 (s, 1H, H2), 7.07 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H5,7), 4.37 (q, 4H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 3.71 (t, 4H, J = 5.2 Hz, piperidine), 1.77 (br. s, 6H, piperidine), 1.41 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 165.8, 160.9, 138.4, 136.6, 135.8, 116.6, 115.5, 59.5, 50.4, 25.8, 24.2, 14.7 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C21H26NO4, 356.1856; found, 356.1829.

    Compound 2c

    A solution of 1 (175 mg, 0.50 mmol) in morpholine (10 mL) was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h. After the reaction mixture was cooled, the amine was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography with CH2Cl2/EtOAc (50:1) as the eluent to afford 2c (168 mg, 94%) as orange crystals. Mp: 162–164 °C (Lit. 101–102 °C); (10) IR (AT-IR): νmax = 2977 (w, C–H), 2903 (w, C–H), 1683 (m, C = O) cm –1; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.41 (d, 2H, J = 11.4 Hz, H4,8), 8.38 (s, 1H, H2), 7.09 (d, 2H, J = 11.4 Hz, H5,7), 4.38 (q, 4H, J = 7.1 Hz, CO2Et), 3.89 (t, 4H, J = 4.8 Hz, morpholine), 3.67 (t, 4H, J = 4.8 Hz, morpholine), 1.42 (t, 6H, J = 7.1 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 165.7, 160.9, 138.5, 137.5, 137.1, 116.8, 116.0, 66.5, 59.7, 49.0, 14.7 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C20H24NO5, 358.1649; found, 358.1667.

    Compound 2d

    A solution of 1 (351 mg, 1.00 mmol) in azepane (10 mL) was stirred at 100 °C for 2 h. The reaction mixture was poured into a 10% HCl solution and extracted with CHCl3. The organic layer was washed with brine, dried with Na2SO4, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography with CH2Cl2 as the eluent to afford 2d (299 mg, 81%) as orange crystals. Mp: 112–113 °C; IR (AT-IR): νmax = 2979 (w, C–H), 2939 (w, C–H), 2911 (w, C–H), 2857 (w, C–H), 1669 (s, C = O) cm –1; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.31 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H4,8), 8.26 (s, 1H, H2), 6.97 (d, 2H, J = 12.0 Hz, H5,7), 4.37 (q, 4H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 3.76 (t, 4H, J = 6.0 Hz, azepane), 1.91 (br. s, 4H, azepane), 1.62–1.60 (m, 4H, azepane), 1.41 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 166.0, 159.6, 138.4, 136.0, 135.1, 115.3, 114.2, 59.5, 51.9, 26.7, 26.4, 14.8 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C22H28NO4, 370.2013; found, 370.2030.

    Compound 2e

    A solution of 1 (351 mg, 1.00 mmol) in N-ethylpiperazine (10 mL) was stirred at 100 °C for 2 h. The reaction mixture was poured into a 10% HCl solution and extracted with CHCl3. The organic layer was washed with brine, dried with Na2SO4, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography with CH2Cl2 as the eluent to afford 2e (319 mg, 83%) as orange crystals. Mp: 125–127 °C; IR (AT-IR): νmax = 2972 (w, C–H), 1696 (m, C = O) cm –1; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.36 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H4,8), 8.33 (s, 1H, H2), 7.09 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H5,7), 4.37 (q, 4H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 3.72 (t, 4H, J = 5.0 Hz, piperazine), 2.61 (t, 4H, J = 5.0 Hz, piperazine), 2.48 (q, 2H, J = 7.3 Hz, Et), 1.41 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 1.13 (t, 3H, J = 7.2 Hz, Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 165.7, 160.9, 138.4, 137.1, 136.5, 116.9, 115.7, 59.6, 52.6, 52.1, 48.9, 14.7, 12.0 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C22H29N2O4, 385.2122; found, 385.2152.

    Compound 2f

    A solution of 1 (172 mg, 0.49 mmol) in diethylamine (10 mL) was stirred at 80 °C for 3 h. After the reaction mixture was cooled, the amine was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography with CH2Cl2 as the eluent to afford 2f (159 mg, 95%) as orange crystals. Mp: 174–176 °C (Lit. 171–172 °C); (10) IR (AT-IR): νmax = 2979 (w, C–H), 2933 (w, C–H), 2900 (w, C–H), 1671 (s, C = O) cm –1; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.32 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H4,8), 8.25 (s, 1H, H2), 6.91 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H5,7), 4.37 (q, 4H, J = 7.1 Hz, CO2Et), 3.63 (q, 4H, J = 7.2 Hz, Et), 1.41 (t, 6H, J = 7.1 Hz, CO2Et), 1.34 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 165.9, 158.6, 138.4, 135.9, 135.0, 115.3, 114.0, 59.5, 46.6, 14.8, 12.1 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C20H26NO4, 344.1856; found, 344.1854.

    Compound 2g

    A solution of 1 (132 mg, 0.38 mmol) in n-butylamine (10 mL) was refluxed for 2 h. After the reaction mixture was cooled, the amine was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography with CH2Cl2/EtOAc (20:1) as the eluent to afford 2g (92 mg, 71%) as orange crystals. Mp: 179–180 °C; IR (AT-IR): νmax = 3335 (w, N–H), 2962 (w, C–H), 2937 (w, C–H), 2902 (w, C–H), 2870 (w, C–H), 1667 (s, C = O) cm –1; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.34 (d, 2H, J = 11.4 Hz, H4,8), 8.27 (s, 1H, H2), 6.75 (d, 2H, J = 11.4 Hz, H5,7), 5.37 (s, 1H, NH), 4.37 (q, 4H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 3.32 (q, 2H, J = 7.2 Hz, n-Bu), 1.71 (t, 2H, J = 7.2 Hz, n-Bu), 1.47 (q, 2H, J = 7.2 Hz, n-Bu), 1.42 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 0.99 (t, 3H, J = 7.2 Hz, n-Bu) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 165.9, 159.6, 139.2, 136.2, 135.2, 115.8, 59.6, 43.7, 30.9, 20.3, 14.7, 13.8 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C20H26NO4, 344.1856; found, 344.1834.

    Compound 2h

    A solution of 1 (170 mg, 0.50 mmol) in tert-butylamine (10 mL) was refluxed for 7 h. After the reaction mixture was cooled, the amine was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography with CH2Cl2 as the eluent to afford 2h (85 mg, 50%) as orange crystals. Mp: 173–175 °C; IR (AT-IR): νmax = 3317 (w, N–H), 2983 (w, C–H), 2935 (w, C–H), 2902 (w, C–H), 1685 (m, C = O) cm –1; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.32 (d, 2H, J = 11.6 Hz, H4,8), 8.26 (s, 1H, H2), 6.88 (d, 2H, J = 11.6 Hz, H5,7), 5.34 (s, 1H, NH), 4.37 (q, 4H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 1.54 (s, 9H, t-Bu), 1.41 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 165.9, 159.2, 138.8, 136.3, 135.3, 116.7, 115.7, 59.6, 53.1, 29.5, 14.7 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C20H26NO4, 344.1856; found, 344.1843.

    Compound 2i

    A solution of 1 (351 mg, 1.00 mmol) in N,N-dimethylethylenediamine (10 mL) was stirred at 100 °C for 3 h. The reaction mixture was poured into a 10% HCl solution and extracted with CHCl3. The organic layer was washed with brine, dried with Na2SO4, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography with CH2Cl2 as the eluent to afford 2i (337 mg, 94%) as orange crystals. Mp: 88–89 °C; IR (AT-IR): νmax = 3330 (w, N–H), 2981 (w, C–H), 2873 (w, C–H), 1666 (s, C = O) cm –1; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.34 (d, 2H, J = 11.2 Hz, H4,8), 8.26 (s, 1H, H2), 6.77 (d, 2H, J = 11.2 Hz, H5,7), 6.29 (s, 1H, NH), 4.36 (q, 4H, J = 7.1 Hz, CO2Et), 3.34 (q, 2H, J = 5.6 Hz, CH2), 2.67 (t, 2H, J = 5.6 Hz, CH2), 2.31 (s, 6H, NMe2), 1.41 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 165.9, 159.5, 139.3, 136.2, 135.2, 115.7, 59.6, 56.5, 44.9, 40.3, 14.7 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C20H27N2O4, 359.1965; found, 359.1988.

    Compound 2j

    A solution of 1 (351 mg, 1.00 mmol) in N,N-dimethylpropylenediamine (10 mL) was stirred at 100 °C for 3 h. The reaction mixture was poured into a 10% HCl solution and extracted with CHCl3. The organic layer was washed with brine, dried with Na2SO4, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography with CH2Cl2 as the eluent to afford 2j (361 mg, 97%) as orange crystals.     Compound 3a

    A solution of 2a (342 mg, 1.00 mmol) in 100% H3PO4 (20 mL) was stirred at 90 °C for 2 h. The reaction mixture was cooled, poured into water, neutralized by K2CO3, and extracted with CH2Cl2. The crude product was purified by alumina column chromatography with CH2Cl2 as the eluent to afford 3a (183 mg, 93%) as red crystals. Mp: 210–212 °C; IR (AT-IR): νmax = 3081 (w, C–H), 3064 (w, C–H), 2976 (w, C–H), 2925 (w, C–H), 2865 (w, C–H) cm–1; UV/vis (CH 2Cl2): λmax = 311 sh (4.66), 321 (4.72), 370 sh (3.85), 381 sh (4.03), 392 sh (4.27), 401 (4.43), 470 (3.16) nm; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ H = 8.03 (d, 2H, J = 10.9 Hz, H4,8), 7.30 (t, 1H, J = 3.5 Hz, H2), 7.09 (d, 2H, J = 3.5 Hz, H1,3), 6.37 (d, 2H, J = 10.9 Hz, H5,7), 3.54 (t, 4H, J = 6.6 Hz, pyrrolidine), 2.10–2.08 (m, 4H, pyrrolidine) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 155.9, 136.9, 132.1, 127.4, 117.8, 107.9, 49.2, 25.7 ppm; HRMS (EI-double-focusing, positive) m/z: [M]+ calcd for C14H15N, 197.1199; found, 197.1210.

    Compound 3b

    A solution of 2b (355 mg, 1.00 mmol) in 100% H3PO4 (20 mL) was stirred at 90 °C for 1.5 h. The reaction mixture was cooled, poured into water, neutralized by K2CO3, and extracted with CH2Cl2.     Compound 3c

    Compound 4

    A solution of 2a (847 mg, 2.48 mmol) and Br2 (1.55 g, 9.70 mmol) in CHCl3 (20 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 20 h. After the reaction was completed, generated precipitate was collected by filtration. The crude product was recrystallized from EtOH to give 4 (817 mg, 78%) as yellow crystals.     Compound 5

    A solution of 2b (500 mg, 1.41 mmol) and Br2 (1.55 g, 9.70 mmol) in CHCl3 (10 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 23 h.     Compound 6

    Compound 7

    A solution of 4 (339 mg, 0.81 mmol) in pyrrolidine (10 mL) was refluxed for 17.5 h. After the reaction mixture was cooled, the amine was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography with hexane/EtOAc (1:1) as the eluent to afford 7 (326 mg, 98%) as orange crystals.     Compound 8

    A solution of 7 (326 mg, 0.79 mmol) and Br2 (620 mg, 3.88 mmol) in CHCl3 (10 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 2 h.     Compound 9

    To a solution of 4 (216 mg, 0.51 mmol), phenylboronic acid (95 mg, 0.78 mmol), and K2CO3 (214 mg, 1.55 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (5 mL) and H2O (1 mL) was added [Pd(PPh3)4] (26 mg, 0.022 mmol). The resulting mixture was refluxed for 18.5 h under an Ar atmosphere. The reaction mixture was poured into water and extracted with CH2Cl2. The organic layer was washed with brine, dried with Na2SO4, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with CH2Cl2 to give 9 (209 mg, 97%) as orange crystals. Mp: 185–186 °C; IR (AT-IR): νmax = 2980 (w, C–H), 2899 (w, C–H), 2845 (w, C–H), 1663 (s, C = O) cm –1; UV/vis (CH 2Cl2): λmax = 261 (4.25), 276 (4.27), 285 sh (4.22), 348 (4.85), 397 (4.50), 430 sh (3.98) nm; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.22 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H4,8), 7.31–7.26 (m, 5H, o,m,p-Ph), 6.79 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H5,7), 4.03 (q, 4H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 3.59 (t, 4H, J = 6.4 Hz, pyrrolidine), 2.13 (t, 4H, J = 6.4 Hz, pyrrolidine), 0.88 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 166.6, 157.4, 147.6, 140.6, 138.3, 134.5, 129.3, 126.6, 125.8, 116.0, 114.9, 59.3, 49.5, 25.6, 13.7 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C26H27NO4, 418.2013; found, 418.2044.

    Compound 10

    To a degassed solution of 4 (210 mg, 0.50 mmol), phenylacetylene (77 mg, 0.75 mmol), and CuI (48 mg, 0.25 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (3 mL) and triethylamine (3 mL) was added [Pd(PPh3)4] (17 mg, 0.015 mmol). The resulting mixture was stirred at 90 °C for 15 h under an Ar atmosphere. The reaction mixture was poured into a 10% NH4Cl solution and extracted with toluene. The organic layer was washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with CH2Cl2 to give 10 (196 mg, 89%) as orange crystals. Mp: 216–217 °C; IR (AT-IR): νmax = 2982 (w, C–H), 2956 (w, C–H), 2878 (w, C–H), 2205 (w, C≡C), 1694 (m, C = O) cm –1; UV/vis (CH 2Cl2): λmax = 280 sh (4.22), 307 sh (4.37), 351 (4.85), 426 (4.72) nm; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.18 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H4,8), 7.59 (d, 2H, J = 6.9 Hz, o-Ph), 7.38–7.31 (m, 3H, m,p-Ph), 6.70 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H5,7), 4.45 (q, 4H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 3.57 (t, 4H, J = 6.6 Hz, pyrrolidine), 2.13 (t, 4H, J = 6.6 Hz, pyrrolidine), 1.43 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 165.9, 157.6, 138.3, 134.7, 131.5, 128.3, 127.8, 124.9, 123.9, 118.4, 115.3, 98.2, 88.5, 59.9, 49.7, 25.5, 14.8 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C28H28NO4, 442.2013; found, 442.2000; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + Ag]+ calcd for C28H27NO4Ag, 548.0986; found, 548.0944.

    Compound 11

    TCNE (40 mg, 0.31 mmol) was added to a solution of 10 (67 mg, 0.15 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (5 mL). The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h under an Ar atmosphere. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with CH2Cl2/EtOAc (50:1) to give 11 (81 mg, 94%) as purple crystals. Mp: 150–152 °C; IR (AT-IR): νmax = 2978 (w, C–H), 2222 (w, C≡N), 1665 (m, C═O) cm –1; UV/vis (CH 2Cl2): λmax = 257 (4.30), 298 sh (4.36), 343 (4.78), 392 (4.49), 532 (3.62), 593 sh (3.43) nm; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.20 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H4,8), 7.84 (d, 2H, J = 7.6 Hz, o-Ph), 7.65 (t, 1H, J = 7.6 Hz, p-Ph), 7.57 (t, 2H, J = 7.6 Hz, m-Ph), 6.83 (d, 2H, J = 11.7 Hz, H5,7), 4.45–4.40 (m, 4H, CO2Et), 3.67 (d, 4H, J = 5.4 Hz, pyrrolidine), 2.19 (br. s, 4H, pyrrolidine), 1.44 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 166.5, 165.5, 164.7, 159.4, 140.6, 135.1, 134.0, 133.7, 133.0, 130.7, 129.5, 117.6, 116.4, 113.6, 113.2, 110.24, 110.21, 93.2, 90.7, 60.8, 50.2, 25.5, 14.6 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C34H28N5O4, 570.2136; found, 570.2132.

    Compound 13a

    To a solution of 1 (702 mg, 2.00 mmol) in EtOH (20 mL) was added phenylhydrazine (1.08 g, 10.0 mmol). The resulting mixture was refluxed for 18 h under an Ar atmosphere. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was passed through an alumina column with CH2Cl2 as an eluent to give crude product 12a. Pb(OAc)4 (1.33 g, 3.00 mmol) and 80% N2H4 (5 drops) in CH2Cl2 (50 mL) was added to a solution of the crude product 12a in CH2Cl2 (50 mL) at room temperature. The resulting mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 5 h under an Ar atmosphere. The reaction mixture was poured into water, extracted with CH2Cl2, and dried with Na2SO4. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was purified by column chromatography on alumina with CH2Cl2 to give 13a (632 mg, 84%) as dark green crystals. Mp: 168–169 °C; IR (AT-IR): νmax = 2980 (w, C–H), 2929 (w, C–H), 1684 (m, C = O), 1587 (w, N = N) cm –1; UV/vis (CH 2Cl2): λmax = 244 (4.40), 267 sh (4.28), 348 (4.64), 375 sh (4.50), 396 sh (4.24), 466 (3.36), 493 sh (3.33), 592 sh (2.93) nm; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.94 (d, 2H, J = 11.2 Hz, H4,8), 8.88 (s, 1H, H2), 8.34 (d, 2H, J = 11.2 Hz, H5,7), 8.06–8.04 (m, 2H, o-Ph), 7.59–7.58 (m, 3H, m,p-Ph), 4.46 (q, 4H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 1.48 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{ 1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 164.9, 158.8, 152.5, 144.7, 143.6, 138.3, 132.7, 129.4, 125.2, 123.8, 117.3, 60.3, 14.7 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C22H21N2O4, 377.1496; found, 377.1491.

    Compound 13b

    To a solution of 1 (702 mg, 2.00 mmol) in EtOH (20 mL) was added p-tolylhydrazine (1.23 g, 10.0 mmol). The resulting mixture was refluxed for 16 h under an Ar atmosphere. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was passed through an alumina column with CH2Cl2 as an eluent to give crude product 12b. Pb(OAc)4 (1.33 g, 3.00 mmol) and 80% N2H4 (5 drops) in CH2Cl2 (50 mL) was added to a solution of the crude product 12b in CH2Cl2 (50 mL) at room temperature. The resulting mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 4 h under an Ar atmosphere. The reaction mixture was poured into water, extracted with CH2Cl2, and dried with Na2SO4. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was purified by column chromatography on alumina with CH2Cl2 to give 13b (703 mg, 90%) as dark green crystals. Mp: 192–193 °C; IR (AT-IR): ν max = 2980 (w, C–H), 2906 (w, C–H), 1684 (m, C = O), 1578 (w, N = N) cm –1; UV/vis (CH 2Cl2): λmax = 246 (4.45), 270 sh (4.24), 359 (4.61), 375 (4.59), 398 sh (4.40), 489 sh (3.27) nm; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.92 (d, 2H, J = 11.2 Hz, H4,8), 8.86 (s, 1H, H2), 8.32 (d, 2H, J = 11.2 Hz, H5,7), 7.94 (d, 2H, J = 8.2 Hz, o-Ph), 7.37 (d, 2H, J = 8.2 Hz, m-Ph), 4.46 (q, 4H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 2.48 (s, 3H, Me), 1.47 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 165.0, 159.0, 150.8, 144.4, 143.7, 143.5, 138.3, 130.1, 125.2, 123.9, 117.2, 60.3, 21.8, 14.7 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C23H23N2O4, 391.1652; found, 391.1642; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + Ag]+ calcd for C23H22N2O4Ag, 497.0625; found, 497.0638.

    Compound 13c

    To a solution of 1 (702 mg, 2.00 mmol) in EtOH (20 mL) was added p-chlorophenylhydrazine (1.43 g, 10.0 mmol). The resulting mixture was refluxed for 20 h under an Ar atmosphere. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was passed through an alumina column with CH2Cl2 as an eluent to give crude product 12c. Pb(OAc)4 (1.33 g, 3.00 mmol) and 80% N2H4 (5 drops) in CH2Cl2 (50 mL) was added to a solution of the crude product 12c in CH2Cl2 (50 mL) at room temperature. The resulting mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 8 h under an Ar atmosphere. The reaction mixture was poured into water, extracted with CH2Cl2, and dried with Na2SO4. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was purified by column chromatography on alumina with CH2Cl2 to give 13a (715 mg, 87%) as dark green crystals. Mp: 202–203 °C; IR (AT-IR): ν max = 3094 (w, C–H), 2984 (w, C–H), 2904 (w, C–H), 1683 (m, C = O), 1582 (w, N = N) cm –1; UV/vis (CH 2Cl2): λmax = 245 (4.43), 268 sh (4.28), 355 (4.65), 375 sh (4.57), 398 sh (4.35), 477 (3.20), 587 sh (2.97) nm; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ H = 9.92 (d, 2H, J = 11.2 Hz, H4,8), 8.87 (s, 1H, H2), 8.31 (d, 2H, J = 11.2 Hz, H5,7), 7.98 (d, 2H, J = 8.7 Hz, o-Ph), 7.55 (d, 2H, J = 8.7 Hz, m-Ph), 4.46 (q, 4H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et), 1.47 (t, 6H, J = 7.2 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 164.9, 158.4, 150.8, 144.8, 143.6, 138.9, 138.2, 129.7, 125.2, 125.0, 117.4, 60.3, 14.7 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C22H20N2O4Cl, 411.1106; found, 411.1102; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + Ag]+ calcd for C22H19N2O4ClAg, 517.0079; found, 517.0075;

    Compound 13d

    To a solution of 1 (702 mg, 2.00 mmol) in EtOH (20 mL) was added p-methoxyphenylhydrazine (1.38 g, 10.0 mmol). The resulting mixture was refluxed for 12 h under an Ar atmosphere. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was passed through an alumina column with CH2Cl2 as an eluent to give crude product 12d. Pb(OAc)4 (1.33 g, 3.00 mmol) and 80% N2H4 (5 drops) in CH2Cl2 (50 mL) was added to a solution of the crude product 12d in CH2Cl2 (50 mL) at room temperature. The resulting mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 1 h under an Ar atmosphere. The reaction mixture was poured into water, extracted with CH2Cl2, and dried with Na2SO4. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was purified by column chromatography on alumina with CH2Cl2 to give 13d (16 mg, 2%) as brown crystals. Mp: 167–168 °C; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 9.91 (d, 2H, J = 11.2 Hz, H4,8), 8.84 (s, 1H, H2), 8.31 (d, 2H, J = 11.2 Hz, H5,7), 8.05 (d, 2H, J = 8.9 Hz, o-Ph), 7.07 (d, 2H, J = 8.9 Hz, m-Ph), 4.45 (q, 4H, J = 7.1 Hz, CO2Et), 3.93 (s, 3H, OMe), 1.47 (t, 6H, J = 7.1 Hz, CO2Et) ppm; 13C{ 1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 165.0, 163.6, 159.3, 147.2, 144.2, 143.4, 138.3, 126.1, 125.2, 117.1, 114.7, 60.3, 55.9, 14.7 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + H]+ calcd for C23H23N2O5, 407.1601; found, 407.1578. Low product yield hampered the measurement of IR and UV/vis spectra.

    Compound 14

    A solution of 13a (377 mg, 1.00 mmol) in 100% H3PO4 (10 mL) was stirred at 90 °C for 30 min. The reaction mixture was cooled, poured into ice-cooled water, neutralized by K2CO3, and extracted with CH2Cl2. The crude product was purified by alumina column chromatography with hexane/CH2Cl2 (10:1) as the eluent to afford 14 (28 mg, 12%) as green crystals. Mp: 172–173 °C; IR (AT-IR): νmax = 3093 (w, C–H), 2984 (w, C–H), 2903 (w, C–H), 1581 (w, N = N) cm –1; UV/vis (CH 2Cl2): λmax = 265 (4.29), 315 sh (4.60), 323 (4.61), 390 (4.22), 471 sh (3.05), 658 (2.66) nm; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δH = 8.52 (d, 2H, J = 10.6 Hz, H4,8), 8.02–8.00 (m, 2H, o-Ph), 7.97 (t, 1H, J = 3.6 Hz, H2), 7.91 (d, 2H, J = 10.6 Hz, H5,7), 7.58–7.53 (m, 3H, m,p-Ph), 7.45 (d, 2H, J = 3.7 Hz, H1,3) ppm; 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δC = 156.9, 152.6, 140.2, 138.9, 135.3, 131.7, 129.3, 123.4, 119.3, 118.4 ppm; HRMS (MALDI–TOF, positive) m/z: [M + Ag]+ calcd for C16H12N2Ag, 339.0046; found, 339.0040.

      1b
      Novel Benzo[b]thiophene Derivatives as New Potential Antidepressants with Rapid Onset of Action
      Berrade, Luis; Aisa, Barbara; Ramirez, Maria J.; Galiano, Silvia; Guccione, Salvatore; Moltzau, Lise Roman; Levy, Finn Olav; Nicoletti, Ferdinando; Battaglia, Giuseppe; Molinaro, Gemma; Aldana, Ignacio; Monge, Antonio; Perez-Silanes, Silvia
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2011), 54 (8), 3086-3090CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      Benzo[b]thiophene derivs. were synthesized according to a dual strategy. Compds. I-III with affinity values toward 5-HT7R and 5-HTT were selected to probe their antidepressant activity in vivo using the forced swimming test (FST). The results showed significant antidepressant activity after chronic treatment. II was effective in reducing the immobility time in FST even after acute treatment. These findings identify these compds. as a new class of antidepressants with a rapid onset of action.

    2. 2

      2a
      Quantitative Determination of Organic Semiconductor Microstructure from the Molecular to Device Scale
      Rivnay, Jonathan; Mannsfeld, Stefan C. B.; Miller, Chad E.; Salleo, Alberto; Toney, Michael F.
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (10), 5488-5519CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. The review show cases some of the advances of x-ray based techniques and assocd. quant. anal. of org. semiconductor films, esp. on structure property relationship.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtFKgu7nE&md5=ee2a2d3e4838518519d52dab6501d7e2

      (b) Feser, S.; Meerholz, K. Investigation of the Photocross-Linking Mechanism in Oxetane-Functionalized Semiconductors. Chem. Mater. 2011, 23, 5001– 5005,  DOI: 10.1021/cm202327c
      [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar

      open URL
      .
      (c) Yuan, W.-Z.; Gong, Y.; Chen, S.; Shen, X.-Y.; Lam, J. W. Y.; Lu, P.; Lu, Y.; Wang, Z.; Hu, R.; Xie, N.; Kwok, H.-S.; Zhang, Y.; Sun, J.-Z.; Tang, B.-Z. Efficient Solid Emitters with Aggregation-Induced Emission and Intramolecular Charge Transfer Characteristics: Molecular Design, Synthesis, Photophysical Behaviors, and OLED Application. Chem. Mater. 2012, 24, 1518– 1528,  DOI: 10.1021/cm300416y
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2c
      Efficient Solid Emitters with Aggregation-Induced Emission and Intramolecular Charge Transfer Characteristics: Molecular Design, Synthesis, Photophysical Behaviors, and OLED Application
      Yuan, Wang Zhang; Gong, Yongyang; Chen, Shuming; Shen, Xiao Yuan; Lam, Jacky W. Y.; Lu, Ping; Lu, Yawei; Wang, Zhiming; Hu, Rongrong; Xie, Ni; Kwok, Hoi Sing; Zhang, Yongming; Sun, Jing Zhi; Tang, Ben Zhong
      Chemistry of Materials (2012), 24 (8), 1518-1528CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      Emissive electron donor-acceptor (D-A) conjugates have a wide variety of applications in biophotonics, 2-photon absorption materials, org. lasers, long wavelength emitters, and so forth. However, it is still a challenge to synthesize high solid-state efficiency D-A structured emitters due to the notorious aggregation-caused quenching (ACQ) effect. Though some D-A systems are reported to show aggregation-induced emission (AIE) behaviors, most are only selectively AIE-active in highly polar solvents, showing decreased solid-sate emission efficiencies compared to those in nonpolar solvents. Here the authors report the triphenylamine (TPA) and 2,3,3-triphenylacrylonitrile (TPAN) based D-A architectures, namely, TPA3TPAN and DTPA4TPAN. Decoration of arylamines with TPAN changes their emission behaviors from ACQ to AIE, making resulting TPA3TPAN and DTPA4TPAN nonluminescent in common solvents but highly emissive when aggregated as nanoparticles, solid powders, and thin films owing to their highly twisted configurations. Both compds. also display a bathochromic effect due to their intramol. charge transfer (ICT) attribute. Combined ICT and AIE features render TPA3TPAN and DTPA4TPAN intense solid yellow emitters with quantum efficiencies of 33.2% and 38.2%, resp. They are also thermally and morphol. stable, with decompn. and glass transition temps. (Td/Tg) being 365/127 and 377/141°, resp. Multilayer electroluminescence (EL) devices are constructed, which emit yellow EL with max. luminance, current, power, and external quantum efficiencies up to 3101 cd/m2, 6.16 cd/A, 2.64 lm/W, and 2.18%, resp. It is promising to fabricate high efficiency AIE-ICT luminogens with tunable emissions through rational combination and modulation of propeller-like donors and/or acceptors, thus paving the way for their biophotonic and optoelectronic applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XltVyltLo%253D&md5=48effc211722cc6fcd9aca497f03dc14
      open URL
    3. 3
      (a) Lo, S.-C.; Burn, P. L. Development of Dendrimers: Macromolecules for Use in Organic Light-Emitting Diodes and Solar Cells. Chem. Rev. 2007, 107, 1097– 1116,  DOI: 10.1021/cr050136l
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3a
      Development of Dendrimers: Macromolecules for Use in Organic Light-Emitting Diodes and Solar Cells
      Lo, Shih-Chun; Burn, Paul L.
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2007), 107 (4), 1097-1116CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Topics include: org. light-emitting diodes and photovoltaic cells; dendrimer structure and synthetic strategy; satd. dendrons; conjugated dendrons; siloles.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXjsVOrsrs%253D&md5=fcec2707c5c895897e116e5293ba8a20
      open URL
      .
      (b) Cheng, Y.-J.; Yang, S.-H.; Hsu, C.-S. Synthesis of Conjugated Polymers for Organic Solar Cell Applications. Chem. Rev. 2009, 109, 5868– 5923,  DOI: 10.1021/cr900182s
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3b
      Synthesis of Conjugated Polymers for Organic Solar Cell Applications
      Cheng, Yen-Ju; Yang, Sheng-Hsiung; Hsu, Chain-Shu
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2009), 109 (11), 5868-5923CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review on synthesis of conjugated polymers for org. solar cells. Particular attention is focused on synthetic approaches directed toward making these polymers as well as highlighting the useful and important building blocks leading to the necessary monomers. The principle of mol. design with band gap engineering, structure-property relationships, and device performances are also discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtF2ltb3M&md5=f42e3fb34251ee8bda3a861c4fb035af
      open URL
      .
      (c) Sun, Y.; Chien, S.-C.; Yip, H.-L.; Zhang, Y.; Chen, K.-S.; Zeigler, D. F.; Chen, F.-C.; Lin, B.; Jen, A. K.-Y. Chemically Doped and Cross-linked Hole-Transporting Materials as an Efficient Anode Buffer Layer for Polymer Solar Cells. Chem. Mater. 2011, 23, 5006– 5015,  DOI: 10.1021/cm2024235
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3c
      Chemically Doped and Cross-linked Hole-Transporting Materials as an Efficient Anode Buffer Layer for Polymer Solar Cells
      Sun, Ying; Chien, Shang-Chieh; Yip, Hin-Lap; Zhang, Yong; Chen, Kung-Shih; Zeigler, David F.; Chen, Fang-Chung; Lin, Baoping; Jen, Alex K.-Y.
      Chemistry of Materials (2011), 23 (22), 5006-5015CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      A series of cross-linkable hole-transporting materials (X-HTMs) consisting of indacenodithiophene, bithiophene, and thiophene units bookended by two triarylamine groups were designed and synthesized to investigate their suitability as new anode buffer layer for bulk heterojunction polymer solar cells (PSCs). These X-HTMs can be thermally cross-linked at temp. between 150-180° to form robust, solvent-resistant films for subsequent spin-coating of another upper layer. Energy levels of these cross-linked materials were measured by cyclic voltammetry, and the data suggest that these X-HTMs have desirable hole-collecting and electron-blocking abilities to function as an anode buffer layer for PSCs. In addn., by incorporating thiophene or fused ring units into the X-HTM backbone, it effectively improved the hole-carrier motilities. To further improve the cond. and optical transparency for PSCs, the X-HTM films were p-doped with nitrosonium hexafluoroantimonate (NOSbF6). The doped X-HTM layers showed remarkably enhanced hole-current densities compared to neutral X-HTM under the same elec. field bias. The properties of the doped X-HTM film as anode buffer layer has been investigated in PSCs. The resulting devices showed similar performance compared to those made using conducting polymer, poly(3,4-ethylene- dioxylenethiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS), as the anode buffer layer. Moreover, a novel bilayer HTM structure consisting of a doped and a neutral layer was employed to exploit the feasibility of combining high cond. from the doped X-HTM and good electron-blocking ability from the neutral X-HTM together. Interestingly, PSC devices based on this bilayer structure showed enhanced Voc, Jsc, and FF compared to the devices with only a single-layer doped X-HTM. These results indicate that such X-HTMs are promising alternative materials to PEDOT:PSS as an anode buffer layer for polymer solar cells.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtlKksLzL&md5=f7dd7c42349fa06f39512df58ad400ac
      open URL
      .
      (d) Ren, X.; Jiang, S.; Cha, M.; Zhou, G.; Wang, Z.-S. Thiophene-Bridged Double D-π-A Dye for Efficient Dye-Sensitized Solar Cell. Chem. Mater. 2012, 24, 3493– 3499,  DOI: 10.1021/cm302250y
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3d
      Thiophene-bridged double D-π-A dye for efficient dye-sensitized solar cell
      Ren, Xiaoming; Jiang, Shenghui; Cha, Mingyang; Zhou, Gang; Wang, Zhong-Sheng
      Chemistry of Materials (2012), 24 (17), 3493-3499CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      An org. dye contg. two D-π-A branches linked with a thiophene unit has been designed and synthesized for efficient dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). As compared to the rod-shape of the single D-π-A analog dye, the cross shape of the double D-π-A branched dye is favorable for reducing intermol. interaction and retarding charge recombination. Controlled intensity modulated photovoltage spectroscopy reveals that electron lifetime for the double D-π-A dye-based DSSC is 14-fold longer than that for the corresponding single D-π-A dye-based DSSC. Linking two D-π-A branches with a thiophene unit increases open-circuit photovoltage by 100 mV and short-circuit photocurrent by 4.10 mA cm-2. As a consequence, power conversion efficiency is enhanced by about 2-fold. This work presents a new route to designing sensitizers with high suppression ability of charge recombination toward high-performance DSSCs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtFGhs77K&md5=aad750a76be3724ace2bebb73c2c0f23
      open URL

      4a
      Organo Lanthanide Metal Complexes for Electroluminescent Materials
      Kido, Junji; Okamoto, Yoshi

      A review. Topics include: org. electroluminescent devices, lanthanide metal ion complexes as the emitting layer, Eu(III) and Tb(III) complexes as emitting materials, Nd(III), Er(III), and Yb(III) complexes as emitting materials, and Tm(III) and Eu(II) complexes as emitting materials.

      (c) Zhang, Y.; Lai, S.-L.; Tong, Q.-X.; Lo, M.-F.; Ng, T.-W.; Chan, M.-Y.; Wen, Z.-C.; He, J.; Kc-Sham, J.; Tang, X.-L.; Liu, W.-M.; Ko, C.-C.; Wang, P.-F.; Lee, C.-S. High Efficiency Nondoped Deep-Blue Organic Light Emitting Devices Based on Imidazole-π-triphenylamine Derivatives. Chem. Mater. 2012, 24, 61– 70,  DOI: 10.1021/cm201789u
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4c
      High Efficiency Nondoped Deep-Blue Organic Light Emitting Devices Based on Imidazole-π-triphenylamine Derivatives
      Zhang, Ying; Lai, Shiu-Lun; Tong, Qing-Xiao; Lo, Ming-Fai; Ng, Tsz-Wai; Chan, Mei-Yee; Wen, Zhi-Chun; He, Jun; Kc-Sham, Jeff; Tang, Xiang-Lin; Liu, Wei-Min; Ko, Chi-Chiu; Wang, Peng-Fei; Lee, Chun-Sing
      Chemistry of Materials (2012), 24 (1), 61-70CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      High-performance deep-blue emitting phenanthroimidazole derivs. with a structure of donor-linker-acceptor were designed and synthesized. By using different linkers and different linking positions, four deep-blue emitters were obtained and used as emitters or bifunctional hole-transporting emitters in OLEDs. Such devices show low turn-on voltages (≥2.8 V), high efficiency (2.63 cd/A, 2.53 lm/W, 3.08%), little efficiency roll-off at high current densities, and stable deep-blue emissions with CIEy < 0.10. Performances are among the best comparing to recently reported deep-blue emitting devices with similar structures. Probably the combination of the phenanthroimidazole and the donor-linker-acceptor structure can be an important approach for developing high performance deep-blue emitters in particular for lighting applications.
