      (e) Lee, J.; Aizawa, N.; Yasuda, T. Isobenzofuranone- and Chromone-Based Blue Delayed Fluorescence Emitters with Low Efficiency Roll-Off in Organic Light-Emitting Diodes. Chem. Mater. 2017, 29, 8012– 8020,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.7b03371
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4e
      Isobenzofuranone- and Chromone-Based Blue Delayed Fluorescence Emitters with Low Efficiency Roll-Off in Organic Light-Emitting Diodes
      Lee, Jiyoung; Aizawa, Naoya; Yasuda, Takuma
      Chemistry of Materials (2017), 29 (18), 8012-8020CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      Significant efforts were devoted to the development of novel efficient blue-emitting mols. for org. light-emitting diode (OLED) applications. Blue org. emitters exhibiting thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) have the potential to achieve ∼100% internal electroluminescence quantum efficiency in OLEDs. The authors report a promising mol. design strategy for obtaining appropriate high singlet and triplet excited energies, short exciton lifetimes, and high quantum efficiencies in blue TADF emitters. The authors introduce isobenzofuranone and chromone contg. a cyclic ketone or lactone moiety as effective acceptor building units to construct donor-acceptor TADF emitters. Owing to their small singlet-triplet energy splitting, properly contracted π-conjugation, and weakened intramol. charge-transfer character, these new emitters display strong blue TADF emissions with high luminescence quantum yields (53-92%) and notably short TADF emission lifetimes (2.8-4.3 μs) in thin films. Blue TADF-OLEDs using these emitters exhibit external electroluminescence quantum efficiencies of up to 16.2% and extremely low efficiency roll-off even at practical high luminance. The current findings open new avenues for designing practically usable high-performance blue TADF emitters with simple mol. structures.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtl2lsLjK&md5=efb9be35b566dba08d6c4cb6f24dc008
      open URL
    5. 5
      (a) Ling, Q.-D.; Liaw, D.-J.; Zhu, C.; Chan, D. S.-H.; Kang, E.-T.; Neoh, K.-G. Polymer electronic memories: Materials, devices and mechanisms. Prog. Polym. Sci. 2008, 33, 917– 978,  DOI: 10.1016/j.progpolymsci.2008.08.001
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5a
      Polymer electronic memories: Materials, devices and mechanisms
      Ling, Qi-Dan; Liaw, Der-Jang; Zhu, Chunxiang; Chan, Daniel Siu-Hung; Kang, En-Tang; Neoh, Koon-Gee
      Progress in Polymer Science (2008), 33 (10), 917-978CODEN: PRPSB8; ISSN:0079-6700. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. As an emerging area in org. electronics, polymer memories have become an active research topic in recent years, because they are likely to be an alternative or supplementary technol. to the conventional memory technol. facing the problems and challenges in miniaturizing from microscale to nanoscale. This review provides a summary of the widely reported elec. switching phenomena in polymers and the corresponding polymer electronic memories. A general introduction to the current state of memory technol. and some basic concepts of electronic memories is first presented, followed by a brief historical development and some key advances in polymer electronic memories. The subsequent sections give a comprehensive review of three categories of polymer electronic memories, classified by drawing the mechanistic analogy between the polymer switching element and one of the three primary circuit elements, viz., capacitor, transistor and resistor. Emphasis is placed on the relationships among material structures and properties, memory devices and operating mechanisms. Finally, the challenges facing the research and development in the field of polymer electronic memories are summarized.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlyqtrnI&md5=942f753c676e123c6bccc9e416e52fe5
      open URL
      .
      (b) Wang, K.-L.; Liu, Y.-L.; Shih, I.-H.; Neoh, K.-G.; Kang, E.-T. Synthesis of polyimides containing triphenylamine-substituted triazole moieties for polymer memory applications. J. Polym. Sci., Part A: Polym. Chem. 2010, 48, 5790– 5800,  DOI: 10.1002/pola.24387
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5b
      Synthesis of polyimides containing triphenylamine-substituted triazole moieties for polymer memory applications
      Wang, Kun-Li; Liu, Yi-Liang; Shih, I.-Hao; Neoh, Koon-Gee; Kang, En-Tang
      Journal of Polymer Science, Part A: Polymer Chemistry (2010), 48 (24), 5790-5800CODEN: JPACEC; ISSN:0887-624X. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      A series of thermally stable arom. polyimides contg. triphenylamine-substituted triazole moieties (AZTA-PI)s were prepd. and characterized. The glass transition temps. (Tg) of the polyimides were in the range of 262-314°. The polyimides obtained by chem. imidization had inherent viscosities of 0.25-0.44 dL g-1 in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone. The no. av. mol. wts. (Mn) and wt. av. mol. wts. (Mw) were 1.9-3.2 × 104 and 3.2-5.6 × 104, resp., and the polydispersity indexes (PDI = Mw/Mn) were in the range of 1.70-1.78. A resistive switching device was constructed from the 4,4'-hexafluoroisopropylidenediphthalic dianhydride-based sol. polyimide (AZTA-PIa) in a sandwich structure of indium-tin oxide/polymer/Al. The as-fabricated device can be switched from the initial low-cond. (OFF) state to the high-cond. (ON) state at a switching threshold voltage of 2.5 V under either pos. or neg. elec. sweep, with an ON/OFF state current ratio in the order of 105 at -1 V. The device is able to remain in the ON state even after turning off the power or under a reverse bias. The nonvolatile and nonrewritable natures of the ON state indicate that the device is a write-once read-many times (WORM) memory.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsVagu7rE&md5=4ad94a4575d503dede30648c67bbfbc9
      open URL
      .
      (c) Wang, K.-L.; Liu, Y.-L.; Lee, J.-W.; Neoh, K.-G.; Kang, E.-T. Nonvolatile Electrical Switching and Write-Once Read-Many-Times Memory Effects in Functional Polyimides Containing Triphenylamine and 1,3,4-Oxadiazole Moieties. Macromolecules 2010, 43, 7159– 7164,  DOI: 10.1021/ma1006446
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5c
      Nonvolatile Electrical Switching and Write-Once Read-Many-Times Memory Effects in Functional Polyimides Containing Triphenylamine and 1,3,4-Oxadiazole Moieties
      Wang, Kun-Li; Liu, Yi-Liang; Lee, Jian-Wei; Neoh, Koon-Gee; Kang, En-Tang
      Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 43 (17), 7159-7164CODEN: MAMOBX; ISSN:0024-9297. (American Chemical Society)
      This work reports the synthesis and characterization of a series of functional arom. polyimides (OXTA-PI)s contg. triphenylamine and 1,3,4-oxadiazole moieties. All the polyimides exhibit high glass transition temps. of 309-319 °C. A resistive switching device with the sandwich structure of indium-tin oxide/polymer/Al was fabricated using the sol. polyimide from 4,4'-hexafluoroisopropylidenediphthalic anhydride (OXTA-PIa). The device exhibits two cond. states and can be switched from the initial low-cond. (OFF) state to the high-cond. (ON) state at the threshold voltages of 1.8 V under both pos. and neg. elec. sweeps, with an ON/OFF state current ratio in the order of 105. The ON state of the device is nonvolatile and can withstand a const. voltage stress of -1 V for 6 h and 108 pulse read cycles at -1 V under ambient conditions. Upon reversing the bias, the ON state cannot be reset to the initial OFF states. The nonvolatile and nonerasable nature of the ON state, as well as the ability to write, read, and sustain the elec. states, fulfills the requirements of a write-once read-many-times (WORM) memory.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      5e
      New donor-acceptor oligoimides for high-performance nonvolatile memory devices
      Lee, Wen-Ya; Kurosawa, Tadanori; Lin, Shiang-Tai; Higashihara, Tomoya; Ueda, Mitsuru; Chen, Wen-Chang
      Chemistry of Materials (2011), 23 (20), 4487-4497CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      We report the synthesis, optoelectronic properties, and elec. switching memory characteristics of three new donor-acceptor oligoimides consisting of the electron-donating moieties (triphenylamine or carbazole) and electron-withdrawing phthalimide moieties (I, II, III). The influence of different donor (D)-acceptor (A) arrangements, including D-A-D and A-D-A structures, on the elec. properties was explored. Devices based on D-A-D oligoimides revealed a reversible nonvolatile neg.-differential-resistance (NDR) characteristic and excellent stability during operation. Without applying voltage stress, the on and off states of the devices showed no obvious degrdn. for an operation time of 10 s and 108 read pulses. However, the devices prepd. from the A-D-A oligoimide showed only the insulating properties. The different memory characteristic was probably because the terminal donor moieties in the D-A-D structure might facilitate the injection and transporting of the holes. Besides, the D-A-D oligoimide with triphenylamine groups exhibited an on/off ratio of 104, 2 orders of magnitude higher than that with carbazole groups. The mechanism related to elec. switching properties was elucidated through mol. simulation. Thus the significance of D-A-D structure on tuning memory characteristics for memory device applications was revealed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXht1Sltr%252FJ&md5=9a0aca918da3d9f325adea94a68704a7
      open URL

      (a) Paul, F.; Patt, J.; Hartwig, J. F. Palladium-catalyzed formation of carbon-nitrogen bonds. Reaction intermediates and catalyst improvements in the hetero cross-coupling of aryl halides and tin amides. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1994, 116, 5969– 5970,  DOI: 10.1021/ja00092a058
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7a
      Palladium-catalyzed formation of carbon-nitrogen bonds. Reaction intermediates and catalyst improvements in the hetero cross-coupling of aryl halides and tin amides
      Paul, Frederic; Patt, Joe; Hartwig, John F.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1994), 116 (13), 5969-70CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      The hetero cross-coupling of aryl bromides and Sn amides by Pd catalysts was studied to understand transition metal mediated C-N bond forming processes and to find more efficient and more general catalysts for this coupling process. The Pd(II) compd. [(o-MeC6H4)3P]2PdX2 (X = Cl 1-Cl, Br 1-Br) is known to catalyze the hetero cross-coupling of Bu3SnNMe2 and phenyl- or p-alkylphenyl bromides at 90-110° in arene solvents to form N,N-dimethylanilines in 75-85% yields. Three complexes were isolated and are kinetically competent intermediates in this catalytic process. The mixed amine/phosphine complexes [(o-tolyl)3P](NHR2)PdCl2 (2) were formed by reaction of 1 with Sn dialkyl amides. These amine complexes were sol. in toluene, catalyzed the coupling process in yields comparable to 1, and were characterized crystallog. The Pd(0) species [(o-tolyl)3P]2Pd (3) was prepd. in pure form by addn. of (o-tolyl)3P to Pd(dba)2 and was also characterized crystallog. This complex catalyzed the coupling chem. with rates that were faster than those involving 1 or 2. The isolation of this pure Pd(0) species allowed a mechanistic anal. of the coupling process. 3 Reacted with aryl halides to yield the dimeric {[(o-tolyl)3P]Pd(Br)(Ar)}2 (4) which was also characterized spectroscopically, crystallog., and by soln. mol. wt. The dimeric form appears to be retained in soln. 4 Reacted with Sn and Li amides to produce the arylamine products in yields comparable to those of the catalytic process. This coupling step involved direct reaction of 4 with the main group amides, strongly suggesting that transmetalation and reductive elimination are the steps that provide coupled product.

      (b) Guram, A. S.; Buchwald, S. L. Palladium-Catalyzed Aromatic Aminations with in situ Generated Aminostannanes. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1994, 116, 7901– 7902,  DOI: 10.1021/ja00096a059
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7b
      Palladium-Catalyzed Aromatic Aminations with in situ Generated Aminostannanes
      Guram, Anil S.; Buchwald, Stephen L.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1994), 116 (17), 7901-2CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      Aminostannes, generated in situ by the transamination reactions of N,N-diethylaminotributyltin with primary and secondary amines, undergo Pd-catalyzed reactions with aryl bromides to afford aryl amines in good yields. Thus, e.g., in situ generation of Bu3SnNMeCH2Ph via transamination of Bu3SnNEt2 with HNMeCH2Ph, followed by reaction with 4-EtO2CC6H4Br in presence of PdCl2[P(o-tolyl)3]2 afforded 88% 4-EtO2CC6H4NMeCH2Ph.

      (c) Littke, A. F.; Fu, G. C. Palladium-Catalyzed Coupling Reactions of Aryl Chlorides. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2002, 41, 4176– 4211,  DOI: 10.1002/1521-3773(20021115)41:22<4176::AID-ANIE4176>3.0.CO;2-U
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7c
      Palladium-catalyzed coupling reactions of aryl chlorides
      Littke, Adam F.; Fu, Gregory C.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (22), 4176-4211CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. Collectively, palladium-catalyzed coupling reactions represent some of the most powerful and versatile tools available to synthetic org. chemists. Their widespread popularity stems in part from the fact that they are generally tolerant to a large no. of functional groups, which allows them to be employed in a wide range of applications. However, for many years a major limitation of palladium-catalyzed coupling processes has been the poor reactivity of aryl chlorides, which from the standpoints of cost and availability are more attractive substrates than the corresponding bromides, iodides, and triflates. Traditional palladium/triarylphosphine catalysts are only effective for the coupling of certain activated aryl chlorides (for example, heteroaryl chlorides and substrates that bear electron-withdrawing groups), but not for aryl chlorides in general. Since 1998, major advances have been described by a no. of research groups addressing this challenge: catalysts based on bulky, electron-rich phosphines and carbenes have proved to be particularly mild and versatile. This review summarizes both the seminal early work and the exciting recent developments in the area of palladium-catalyzed couplings of aryl chlorides.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XptlGmu7Y%253D&md5=e4e64da85d48165791f3a97c49f2da72
      open URL
      .
      (d) Corbet, J.-P.; Mignani, G. Selected Patented Cross-Coupling Reaction Technologies. Chem. Rev. 2006, 106, 2651– 2710,  DOI: 10.1021/cr0505268
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      8e
      Mechanisms of Nucleophilic Organocopper(I) Reactions
      Yoshikai, Naohiko; Nakamura, Eiichi

      A review of mechanisms of nucleophilic organocopper mediated/catalyzed transformations.

      (b) Yamaguchi, Y.; Ogawa, K.; Nakayama, K.-i.; Ohba, Y.; Katagiri, H. Terazulene: A High-Performance n-Type Organic Field-Effect Transistor Based on Molecular Orbital Distribution Control. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2013, 135, 19095– 19098,  DOI: 10.1021/ja410696j

      9b
      Terazulene: A High-Performance n-Type Organic Field-Effect Transistor Based on Molecular Orbital Distribution Control
      Yamaguchi, Yuji; Ogawa, Keisuke; Nakayama, Ken-ichi; Ohba, Yoshihiro; Katagiri, Hiroshi
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (51), 19095-19098CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The authors present herein a linear expanded π-conjugation system comprising azulene units: 2,6':2',6''-terazulene. This simple hydrocarbon exhibits excellent n-type transistor performance with an electron mobility of up to 0.29 cm2 V-1 s-1. The LUMO is well distributed over the entire mol., whereas the HOMO is localized at one end. These findings indicate a disadvantage of hole carrier transport and an advantage of n-type-specific transport behavior. This system presents an unconventional concept: polarity control of OFET by MO distribution control.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvFegs7nN&md5=8b529e91f19977462b8d36b0e2b5a055
      open URL
      .
      (c) Yao, J.; Cai, Z.; Liu, Z.; Yu, C.; Luo, H.; Yang, Y.; Yang, S.; Zhang, G.; Zhang, D. Tuning the Semiconducting Behaviors of New Alternating Dithienyldiketopyrrolopyrrole–Azulene Conjugated Polymers by Varying the Linking Positions of Azulene. Macromolecules 2015, 48, 2039– 2047,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.macromol.5b00158
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9c
      Tuning the Semiconducting Behaviors of New Alternating Dithienyldiketopyrrolopyrrole-Azulene Conjugated Polymers by Varying the Linking Positions of Azulene
      Yao, Jingjing; Cai, Zhengxu; Liu, Zitong; Yu, Chenmin; Luo, Hewei; Yang, Yang; Yang, Sifen; Zhang, Guanxin; Zhang, Deqing
      Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States) (2015), 48 (7), 2039-2047CODEN: MAMOBX; ISSN:0024-9297. (American Chemical Society)
      Three new conjugated polymers DPPA1, DPPA2, and DPPA3 with dithienyldiketopyrrolopyrrole (DPP) and azulene moieties were synthesized and characterized. The five-membered rings of azulene are connected with DPP in DPPA1 and DPPA2, whereas the seven-membered ring of azulene is incorporated into the backbone of DPPA3. The LUMO energy of DPPA3, which was detd. on the basis of the resp. cyclic voltammograms and absorption spectra, is lower than those of DPPA1 and DPPA2. OFETs were successfully fabricated with thin films of DPPA1, DPPA2, and DPPA3. Thin films of DPPA1 and DPPA2 exhibit p-type semiconducting properties with hole mobilities up to 0.97 cm2 V-1 s-1, whereas typical ambipolar behavior is found for thin film of DPPA3 with hole and electron mobilities reaching 0.062 cm2 V-1 s-1 and 0.021 cm2 V-1 s-1, resp. The results reveal that semiconducting properties of DPPA1, DPPA2, and DPPA3 can be tuned by varying the linkage positions of azulene with DPP moieties. Furthermore, DPPA1, DPPA2, and DPPA3 were tested preliminarily as photovoltaic materials. The power conversion efficiency (PCE) reaches 2.04% for the blending thin film DPPA1 with PC71BM.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXlslGksrY%253D&md5=052d7a7a828c1498caac7f67354ef5fb
      open URL
      .
      (d) Yamaguchi, Y.; Takubo, M.; Ogawa, K.; Nakayama, K.-i.; Koganezawa, T.; Katagiri, H. Terazulene Isomers: Polarity Change of OFETs through Molecular Orbital Distribution Contrast. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2016, 138, 11335– 11343,  DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b06877
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9d
      Terazulene Isomers: Polarity Change of OFETs through Molecular Orbital Distribution Contrast
      Yamaguchi, Yuji; Takubo, Maki; Ogawa, Keisuke; Nakayama, Ken-ichi; Koganezawa, Tomoyuki; Katagiri, Hiroshi
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2016), 138 (35), 11335-11343CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Intermol. orbital coupling is fundamentally important to org. semiconductor performance. Recently, we reported that 2,6':2',6''-terazulene (TAz1) exhibited excellent performance as an n-type org. field-effect transistor (OFET) via MO distribution control. To validate and develop this concept, here we present three other terazulene regioisomers, which have three azulene mols. connected at the 2- or 6-position along the long axis of the azulene, thus constructing a linear expanded π-conjugation system: 2,2':6',2''-terazulene (TAz2), 2,2':6',6''-terazulene (TAz3), and 6,2':6',6''-terazulene (TAz4). TAz2 and TAz3 exhibit ambipolar characteristics; TAz4 exhibits clear n-type transistor behavior as an OFET. The lowest unoccupied MOs (LUMOs) of all terazulenes are fully delocalized over the entire mol. In contrast, the highest occupied MOs (HOMOs) of TAz2 and TAz3 are delocalized over the 2,2'-biazulene units; the HOMOs of TAz4 are localized at one end of the azulene unit. These findings confirm that terazulene isomers which are simple hydrocarbon compds. are versatile materials with a tunable-polarity FET characteristic that depends on the direction of the azulene unit and the related contrast of the MO distribution in the terazulene backbone.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhtlamt7%252FE&md5=5790295ef63374615f95acd244a0e057
      open URL
      .
      (e) Xin, H.; Ge, C.; Yang, X.; Gao, H.; Yang, X.; Gao, X. Biazulene diimides: a new building block for organic electronic materials. Chem. Sci. 2016, 7, 6701– 6705,  DOI: 10.1039/C6SC02504H
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9e
      Biazulene diimides: a new building block for organic electronic materials
      Xin, Hanshen; Ge, Congwu; Yang, Xiaodi; Gao, Honglei; Yang, Xiaochun; Gao, Xike
      Chemical Science (2016), 7 (11), 6701-6705CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Azulene, a 10-π-electron isomer of naphthalene, is a nonbenzenoid bicyclic arom. hydrocarbon with a beautiful blue color and a large dipole moment. We present here the first class of azulene-based arom. diimides, 2,2'-biazulene-1,1',3,3'-tetracarboxylic diimides (BAzDIs), which comprise a 2,2'-biazulene moiety and two seven-membered imide groups. DFT calcns., thermal, optical and electrochem. properties of two BAzDI derivs. as well as single crystal anal. and the charge transport behavior were studied. The results demonstrate that BAzDIs have unique photophys. properties and are promising for org. electronic materials.

      (f) Xin, H.; Ge, C.; Jiao, X.; Yang, X.; Rundel, K.; McNeill, C. R.; Gao, X. Incorporation of 2,6-Connected Azulene Units into the Backbone of Conjugated Polymers: Towards High-Performance Organic Optoelectronic Materials. Angew. Chem., Int.       [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9f
      Incorporation of 2,6-Connected Azulene Units into the Backbone of Conjugated Polymers: Towards High-Performance Organic Optoelectronic Materials
      Xin, Hanshen; Ge, Congwu; Jiao, Xuechen; Yang, Xiaodi; Rundel, Kira; McNeill, Christopher R.; Gao, Xike
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2018), 57 (5), 1322-1326CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Azulene is a promising candidate for constructing optoelectronic materials. An effective strategy is presented to obtain high-performance conjugated polymers by incorporating 2,6-connected azulene units into the polymeric backbone, and 2 conjugated copolymers P(TBAzDI-TPD) and P(TBAzDI-TFB) were designed and synthesized based on this strategy. They are the 1st 2 examples for 2,6-connected azulene-based conjugated polymers and exhibit unipolar n-type transistor performance with an electron mobility of up to 0.42 cm2 V-1 s-1, which is among the highest values for n-type polymeric semiconductors in bottom-gate top-contact org. field-effect transistors. Preliminary all-polymer solar cell devices with P(TBAzDI-TPD) as the electron acceptor and PTB7-Th as the electron donor display a power conversion efficiency of 1.82%.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      (g) Xin, H.; Li, J.; Ge, C.; Yang, X.; Xue, T.; Gao, X. 6,6’-Diaryl-substituted biazulene diimides for solution-processable high-performance n-type organic semiconductors. Mater. Chem. Front. 2018, 2, 975– 985,  DOI: 10.1039/C8QM00047F
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9g
      6,6'-Diaryl-substituted biazulene diimides for solution-processable high-performance n-type organic semiconductors
      Xin, Hanshen; Li, Jing; Ge, Congwu; Yang, Xiaodi; Xue, Tianrui; Gao, Xike
      Materials Chemistry Frontiers (2018), 2 (5), 975-985CODEN: MCFAC5; ISSN:2052-1537. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Azulene, a non-benzenoid arom. hydrocarbon, is a promising building block for constructing org. optoelectronic materials. Herein, a series of 6,6'-diaryl-substituted biazulene diimides (1-5) are designed and synthesized for soln.-processable org. semiconductors. These compds. exhibited excellent electron transport properties with fine-tuned mol. energy levels (HOMO: -5.68 to -6.04 eV; LUMO: -3.63 to -3.73 eV). Bottom-gate-top-contact org. field effect transistors (OFETs) based on compds. 1-3 and 5 displayed unipolar n-type semiconducting properties with optimized av. electron mobilities of 0.12-0.45 cm2 V-1 s-1, of which the devices based on 2 demonstrated an electron mobility of up to 0.52 cm2 V-1 s-1, the highest electron mobilities for azulene-based org. semiconductors and also among the highest values for soln.-processable n-channel OFETs. Devices based on 4 showed ambipolar FET performance with electron and hole mobilities of 0.31 cm2 V-1 s-1 and 0.029 cm2 V-1 s-1, resp. The ambipolar charge transport behavior of 4 is due to its higher HOMO energy level (-5.68 eV) than the others (-5.78 to -6.04 eV). The excellent electron transport ability of compds. 1-5 might be attributed to the dense mol. packing induced by the dipolar moment of the azulene units as revealed by single crystal anal. Besides, compds. 2 and 5 were used as electron acceptors for org. photovoltaic devices, and an av. power conversion efficiency of about 1.3% was obtained for their resp. blend thin films with electron donor PTB7-Th. The results demonstrate that 6,6-diaryl-substituted biazulene diimides are promising soln.-processable n-type org. semiconductors, and the azulene unit has great potential for constructing excellent org. optoelectronic materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXjvFWqurY%253D&md5=2f2ad6892781af15c059a5bbd618bc90
      open URL

      (a) Puodziukynaite, E.; Wang, H.-W.; Lawrence, J.; Wise, A. J.; Russell, T. P.; Barnes, M. D.; Emrick, T. Azulene Methacrylate Polymers: Synthesis, Electronic Properties, and Solar Cell Fabrication. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2014, 136, 11043– 11049,  DOI: 10.1021/ja504670k
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10a
      Azulene Methacrylate Polymers: Synthesis, Electronic Properties, and Solar Cell Fabrication
      Puodziukynaite, Egle; Wang, Hsin-Wei; Lawrence, Jimmy; Wise, Adam J.; Russell, Thomas P.; Barnes, Michael D.; Emrick, Todd
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (31), 11043-11049CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The authors report the synthesis of novel azulene-substituted methacrylate polymers by free radical polymn., in which the azulene moieties represent hydrophobic dipoles strung pendant to the polymer backbone and impart unique electronic properties to the polymers. Tunable optoelectronic properties were realized by adjusting the azulene d., ranging from homopolymers (having one azulene group per repeat unit) to copolymers in which the azulene d. was dild. with other pendant groups. Treating these polymers with org. acids revealed optical and excitonic behavior that depended critically on the azulene d. along the polymer chain. Copolymers of azulene with zwitterionic methacrylates proved useful as cathode modification layers in bulk-heterojunction solar cells, where the relative azulene content affected the device metrics and the power conversion efficiency reached 7.9%.

      10b
      Hole-Transporting Materials with a Two-Dimensionally Expanded π-System around an Azulene Core for Efficient Perovskite Solar Cells
      Nishimura, Hidetaka; Ishida, Naoki; Shimazaki, Ai; Wakamiya, Atsushi; Saeki, Akinori; Scott, Lawrence T.; Murata, Yasujiro
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2015), 137 (50), 15656-15659CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Two-dimensionally expanded π-systems, consisting of partially oxygen-bridged triarylamine skeletons that are connected to an azulene (1-3) or biphenyl core (4), were synthesized and characterized. When tetra-substituted azulene 1 was used as a hole-transporting material (HTM) in perovskite solar cells, the obsd. performance (power conversion efficiency = 16.5%) was found to be superior to that of the current HTM std. Spiro-OMeTAD. A comparison of the hole mobility, the ability to control the HOMO and LUMO levels, and the hole-collection efficiency at the perovskite/HTM interface in 1 with ref. compds. (2-4 and Spiro-OMeTAD) led to the elucidation of key factors required for HTMs to act efficiently in perovskite solar cells.

      An Azulene-Containing Low Bandgap Small Molecule for Organic Photovoltaics with High Open Circuit Voltage
      Chen, Yao; Zhu, Youqin; Yang, Daobin; Zhao, Suling; Zhang, Lei; Yang, Lin; Wu, Jianglin; Huang, Yan; Xu, Zheng; Lu, Zhiyun
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2016), 22 (41), 14527-14530CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A simple azulene-contg. squaraine dye (AzUSQ) showing bandgap of 1.38 eV and hole mobility up to 1.25 × 10-4 cm2 V-1 s-1 was synthesized. Considering of its low band gap, org. photovoltaic (OPV) device based on it exhibits an impressive Voc of 0.80 V. Hence azulene might be a promising structural unit to construct OPV materials with simultaneous low bandgap, high hole mobility and high Voc.

      Azulene - Thiophene - Cyanoacrylic acid dyes with donor-π-acceptor structures. Synthesis, characterization and evaluation in dye-sensitized solar cells
      Cowper, Paul; Pockett, Adam; Kociok-Kohn, Gabriele; Cameron, Petra J.; Lewis, Simon E.
      Tetrahedron (2018), 74 (22), 2775-2786CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      We report the synthesis of five new azulene contg. dyes, having D-π-A type structures. These dyes are synthesized using a sulfonium salt cross-coupling reaction. The dyes have been evaluated spectroscopically, electrochem., crystallog., and as sensitizers in dye-sensitized solar cells. We propose a rationale for the dyes' spectroscopic properties and performance in cells, based on conformational data derived from their crystal structures.

      11a
      Azulene-Fused Linear Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons with Small Bandgap, High Stability, and Reversible Stimuli Responsiveness
      Murai, Masahito; Iba, Shinji; Ota, Hiromi; Takai, Kazuhiko
      Organic Letters (2017), 19 (20), 5585-5588CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
      Azulene-fused polycyclic arom. hydrocarbons (PAHs) were synthesized from com. available azulene in four steps. The resulting azulene conjugates exhibited significantly narrow HOMO-LUMO bandgaps with high air stability, confirmed by photophys. study. Introduction of azulene also enabled the unique reversible stimuli-responsiveness even with the weak acid and base, which can potentially control the degree of conjugation and optoelectronic properties by simple acid-base and redox processes.

      11b
      2,5-Bis(azulenyl)pyrrolo[3,2-b]pyrroles - the key influence of the linkage position on the linear and nonlinear optical properties
      Poronik, Yevgen M.; Mazur, Leszek M.; Samoc, Marek; Jacquemin, Denis; Gryko, Daniel T.
      Journal of Materials Chemistry C: Materials for Optical and Electronic Devices (2017), 5 (10), 2620-2628CODEN: JMCCCX; ISSN:2050-7534. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The first route towards pyrrolo[3,2-b]pyrroles contg. two azulene moieties at positions 2 and 5 was developed. The key step of this approach is the three-step transformation of pyridine scaffolds into azulene via sequential N-arylation followed by ring-opening and a reaction with cyclopentadiene. The resulting quadrupolar acceptor-donor-acceptor compds. possess interesting optical properties such as bathochromically shifted absorption with the magnitude of the red-shift strongly dependent on the linkage position. Two-photon absorption of these functional dyes is markedly different from that of previously described pyrrolo[3,2-b]pyrroles. The exptl. optical spectra were rationalized using time-dependent d. functional theory calcns. of both the linear and nonlinear optical properties.

      Azulene-boronate esters: colorimetric indicators for fluoride in drinking water
      Lopez-Alled, Carlos M.; Sanchez-Fernandez, Adrian; Edler, Karen J.; Sedgwick, Adam C.; Bull, Steven D.; McMullin, Claire L.; Kociok-Kohn, Gabriele; James, Tony D.; Wenk, Jannis; Lewis, Simon E.
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2017), 53 (93), 12580-12583CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Low cost and in situ F- detection by non-experts is important for the detn. of drinking water safety in developing countries. Color reagents can provide results quickly without expensive equipment, but colorimetric F- indicators are often nonspecific, complex to use or do not work in water. Here we show that azulene-boronate indicators respond selectively to F- at concns. relevant to the WHO limit of 1.5 mg/L.

      13
      On amination and diazotization of azulene and its derivatives
      Makosza, M.; Osinski, P. W.; Ostrowski, S.
      Polish Journal of Chemistry (2001), 75 (2), 275-281CODEN: PJCHDQ; ISSN:0137-5083. (Polish Chemical Society)
      A practical procedure for synthesis of 6-aminoazulene (I) via Vicarious Nucleophilic Substitution of Hydrogen (VNS) amination of azulene with 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole is reported. Amination with use of N,N,N-trimethylhydrazinium iodide of more electrophilic azulene derivs., substituted at position 1 with CN or COPh groups, afforded a mixt. of 4-, 6-, and 8-aminoazulenes. Attempts to convert I into diazonium salt failed, only formation of small quantities of the auto-coupling product, 1-(azulen-6-ylazo)-azulen-6-yl-amine, was obsd.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXhtlWlsbk%253D&md5=99bf75d4fa16955df77b2a8aecc7b832
      open URL
    14. 14
      Nozoe, T.; Seto, S.; Matsumura, S. Synthesis of 2-Substituted Azulenes by Nucleophilic Substitution Reactions of 2-Haloazulene Derivatives. Bull. Chem. Soc. Jpn. 1962, 35, 1990– 1998,  DOI: 10.1246/bcsj.35.1990
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14
      Synthesis of 2-substituted azulenes by nucleophilic substitution reactions of 2-haloazulene derivatives
      Nozoe, Tetsuo; Seto, Shuichi; Matsumura, Shingo
      Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan (1962), 35 (), 1990-8CODEN: BCSJA8; ISSN:0009-2673.
      Dry HCl passed into 6 g. Ia (R = R2 = CO2Et, R1 = NH2) (I) in 200 cc. dry C6H6 with cooling, the mixt. treated with 2.7 g. iso-AmONO, kept at room temp. overnight, washed, and evapd. yielded 5.4 g. 2-Cl analog (II) of I, red prisms, m. 77-8° (EtOH). I (600 mg.) in 20 cc. dry C6H6 satd. with dry HBr treated at room temp. with 270 mg. iso-AmONO, the mixt. kept overnight at room temp. and worked up, and the oily product chromatographed on Al2O3 yielded 150 mg. Ia (R = R2 = CO2Et, R1 = H), m. 120-1° (EtOH). II (5 g.) in 50 cc. 10% 4:1 alc. aq. KOH refluxed 15-30 min., the mixt. cooled, acidified with 6N HNO3, and filtered yielded 4 g. Ia (R = R2 = CO2H, R1 = Cl) (III), m. 260-5° (decompn.). III (1 g.) heated at 265-70°/200 mm.), and the violet cryst. sublimate chromatographed from petr. ether (b. 50-60°) on Al2O3 gave 600 mg. 2-chloroazulene (IV), violet needles, m. 91-2° (MeOH). II (1 g.) refluxed 15 min. with 200 mg. KOH in 10 cc. 4:1 EtOH-H2O, the mixt. acidified with 6N HNO3, and filtered gave 500 mg. crude Ia (tR = CO2Et, R1 = Cl, R2 = CO2H), m. 193-5° (decompn.); the crude material decarboxylated in the usual manner and the product chromatographed on Al2O3 gave about 20 mg. IV and 300 mg. Ia (R = CO2Et, R1 = Cl, R2 = H) (V), reddish violet oil; picrate, red needles, m. 91-2° (EtOH). IV (10 g.) and 200 g. KI in 60 cc. AcOH contg. 50 cc. H2O refluxed 3.5 hrs. at 130-40°, the mixt. dild. with 1000 cc. H2O and filtered, and the residue chromatographed on Al2O3 yielded 12 g. 2-iodoazulene (VI), violet needles, m. 125-6° (MeOH). IV (100 mg.) and 1.5 g. KBr refluxed 4 hrs. with 6 cc. AcOH and 0.5 cc. H2O, and the mixt. dild. with 10 cc. H2O and filtered gave only a black ppt. II (200 mg.) refluxed 2 hrs. with 300 mg. NaOMe in 3 cc. abs. MeOH and evapd., and the residue sepd. into H2O-sol. and -insol. material yielded 120 mg. Ia (R = R2 = CO2Me, R1 = MeO) (VII), orange needles, m. 61-2° (MeOH); the H2O-sol. material neutralized with dil. HNO3 gave 20 mg. Ia (R = CO2H, R1 = MeO, R2 = CO2Me), orange microscales, m. 143-5° (decompn.). II (100 mg.), 1 cc. EtOH, and 1 cc. 28% NH4OH heated 1 hr. at 100° in a sealed tube, cooled, and filtered gave 60 mg. I, orange prisms, m. 93-4° (EtOH). II (200 mg.) in 3 cc. EtOH refluxed 2 hrs. with 3 cc. 10% aq. MeNH2, the mixt. concd., dild. with H2O, and extd. with C6H6, and the residue from the ext. chromatographed on Al2O3 gave 40 mg. unchanged II and 160 mg. red oily 2-MeNH analog (VIII) of I; 1,3,5-CH(NO2)3 adduct, orange needles, m. 100-2° (EtOH). II (200 mg.), 3 cc. 40% aq. Me2NH, and 3 cc. EtOH refluxed 2 hrs., the mixt. dild. with H2O, and filtered yielded 160 mg. 2-Me2N analog of I, orange leaflets, m. 81-2° (ligroine, b. 80-90°). II (100 mg.) in 2 cc. EtOH heated 3 hrs. on a water bath with 60 mg. PhNH2, dild. with H2O, and extd. with C6H6 gave 70 mg. 2-PhNH analog (IX) of I, orange needles, m. 141-2° (EtOH). II (100 mg.), 2 cc. EtOH, and 100 mg. p-BrC6H4NH2 gave similarly the 2-(p-BrC6H4NH) analog of I, orange needles, m. 166-8°. II (100 mg.), 3 cc. EtOH, and 100 mg. 80% N2H4.H2O refluxed 2 hrs. gave 30 mg. bis(1,3-diethoxy-carbonyl-2-azulenyl)hydrazine, orange scales, m. 163-4° (EtOH); the oily residue from the mother liquor chromatographed from C6H6 on Al2O3 gave some unchanged II and 30 mg. 2-H2NNH analog (X), of I, orange oil. X (30 mg.) in 0.3 cc. Me2CO heated 10 min. on a water bath and evapd., and the residue chromatographed on Al2O3 yielded the isopropylidene deriv. of X, orange leaflets, m. 133-4°. X (50 mg.) in 0.5 cc. Ac2O heated 50 min. on a water bath gave the acetate, m. 130-2° (EtOH). II (100 mg.) heated 1 hr. on a water bath with 30 mg. Na, 250 mg. CH2(CO2Et)2, and 1 cc. abs. EtOH, the mixt. evapd., the residue dissolved in H2O, acidified with AcOH, and extd. with C6H6, and the oily residue from the ext. chromatographed on Al2O3 gave 10 mg. II and 60 mg. red oily 2-(EtO2C)2CH analog (XI) of I. II (500 mg.) heated 1 hr. at 90° with 75 mg. Na and 370 mg. NCCH2CO2Et in 5 cc. abs. EtOH gave similarly 470 mg. 2-NC(EtO2C)CH analog (XII) of I, red prisms, m. 116-17° (EtOH). AcCH2CO2Et (400 mg.), 50 mg. Na, and 4 cc. abs. EtOH heated 1 hr. on the water bath with 200 mg. II gave 120 mg. (crude) 2-Ac(EtO2C)CH analog of I, red prisms, m. 53-4° (cyclohexane). V (200 mg.) refluxed 3 hrs. with 100 mg. NaOEt in 3 cc. abs. EtOH, EtOH evapd., and the residue chromatographed on Al2O3 gave 60 mg. unreacted V and 90 mg. Ia (R = CO2Et, R1 = EtO, R2 = H) (XIII), pink prisms, m. 84-5° (EtOH). V heated 1.5 hrs. at 120-30° with 40 mg. Na, 200 mg. NCCH2CO2Et, and 4 cc. abs. EtOH, EtOH evapd., the residue dissolved in H2O, acidified with 6N HNO3, and extd. with C6H6, and the ext. chromatographed on Al2O3 yielded 90 mg. V, 20 mg. XIII, m. 84-5°, and a small amt. violet needles, m. 115-16°. IX (100 mg.), 15 mg. KOH, and 1.5 cc. EtOH refluxed 3 hrs. on a water bath, the mixt. cooled, acidified with 6N HCl, and filtered, the dried residue heated at 160°, and the resulting orange oil chromatographed on Al2O3 yielded 50 mg. orange, oily Ia (R = CO2Et, R1 = PhNH, R2 = H); 1,3,5-C6H3(NO2)3 adduct, brownish orange needles, m. 111-12° (EtOH). VI (50 mg.) and 100 mg. NaOMe in 1 cc. abs. MeOH heated 30 hrs. in a sealed tube at 100° and evapd., and the residue chromatographed on Al2O3 gave 20 mg. 2-methoxyazulene (XIV), reddish violet needles, m. 82-3° (MeOH). IV (100 mg.) and 200 mg. NaOMe in 2 cc. abs. MeOH gave similarly 170 mg. unchanged IV and a small amt. XIV. VII (50 mg.) 0.5 cc. EtOH, and 1 cc. 10% aq. KOH refluxed 2 hrs., the mixt. cooled, acidified with 6N H2SO4, and filtered, and the crude residue (30 mg.) sublimed at 200°/100 mm. yielded 10 mg. red oily XIV. XIII (50 mg.) in 1 cc. 10% aq. KOH gave similarly 20 mg. reddish violet, oily 2-ethoxyazulene. IX (100 mg.) in 2 cc. 10% 4:1 EtOH-H2O soln. of KOH heated 2.5 hrs. on a water bath, the mixt. cooled, acidified with 6N HCl, and filtered, and the dried product decarboxylated at 160°/10 mm. gave 40 mg. 2-anilinoazulene (XV), reddish orange scales, m. 144-5° (petr. ether). III (50 mg.) in 0.5 cc. C5H5N and 100 mg. PhNH2 heated 1 hr. at 120-30° and evapd., and the residue chromatographed on Al2O3 gave about 15 mg. XV, m. 144-5°. VI (5 g.), 5 g. CuCN, and 50 cc. C5H5N heated 0.5 hr. at 140-50°, and evapd., and the residue chromatographed on Al2O3 gave 600 mg. unchanged VI and 2 g. 2-cyanoazulene (XVI), deep blue leaflets, m. 77-8° (MeOH). IV (500 mg.), 500 mg. CuCN, and 5 cc. C5H5N gave similarly 430 mg. unchanged IV and 10 mg. XVI. III (100 mg.) in 3 cc. 80% N2H4.H2O heated 0.5 hr. on the water bath gave 30 mg. 2-hydrazinoazulene, reddish orange leaflets, m. 127-8° (C6H6). III (100 mg.) in 3 cc. 40% aq. Me2NH heated 3 hrs. at 100° in a sealed tube, the mixt. cooled and filtered, and the residue chromatographed on Al2O3 gave 30 mg. 2-dimethylaminoazulene (XVIa), orange leaflets, m. 98-9° (EtOH). X or XII (200 mg.) in 30% 4:1 alc. aq. KOH heated 6 hrs. at 100°, the mixt. cooled, acidified with 6N HCl, and filtered, the residue heated at 260-70°/100 mm., and the resulting violet oil chromatographed on Al2O3 gave 70 mg. (crude) 2-methylazulene, violet needles, m. 49-50° (aq. MeOH). Dry HCl passed into 100 mg. XVI in 3 cc. abs. MeOH, the soln. refluxed 8 hrs. and evapd., and the residue chromatographed on Al2O3 gave 60 mg. 2-carbomethoxyazulene (XVII), blue needles, m. 110-11° (MeOH). XVI (100mg.) in 2cc. 10% 4:1 alc. aq. KOH heated 3 hrs. on the water bath, filtered, and evapd., and the residue dissolved in H2O and neutralized with dil. H2SO4 gave 20 mg. 2-carboxyazulene (XVIII), green needles, m. 200-3° (decompn.) (C6H6). XVII (100 mg.) in 2 cc. 10% 4:1 EtOH-H2O soln. of KOH gave similarly 40 mg. XVIII. XVI (100 mg.) in 0.3 cc. HCONMe2 treated with cooling with 120 mg. POCl3, the mixt. poured into iced H2O, and filtered gave 80 mg. Ia (R = CHO, R1 = CN, R2 = H), reddish violet scales, m. 180-2° (MeOH). I (100 mg.) in 2 cc. CHCl3 treated 2 hrs. at room temp. with 60 mg. Br and filtered yielded 130 mg. 6-Br deriv. of I, orange prisms, m. 163-4° (C6H6). VIII (100 mg.) in 1.5 cc. AcOH treated with 60 mg. Br, kept overnight, and evapd., the residue oil extd. with CHCl3, and the residue from the ext. chromatographed on Al2O3 gave 120 mg. 6-Br deriv. of VIII, m. 98-105° (cyclohexane), which recrystd. from EtOH yielded 90 mg. orange scales, m. 117-18°. IX (100 mg.) in 2 cc. CHCl3 treated 2 hrs. at room temp. with 60 mg. Br and worked up, and the crude product chromatographed on Al2O3 yielded 60 mg. 6-Br deriv. of IX, orange scales, m. 173-4° (EtOH). The visible absorption spectra of IV, VI, XIV, XVI, XVIa, and XVII were recorded.

      15
      Anionoid substitution reaction of diethyl 6-bromoazulene-1,3-dicarboxylate
      Nozoe, Tetsuo; Takase, Kahei; Tada, Masao
      Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan (1965), 38 (2), 247-51CODEN: BCSJA8; ISSN:0009-2673.
      Decompn. of diazotized I (2.0 g.) with 20 g. Na4P2O6 gave 25% red II (X = Br), m. 206-7° (EtOH), v 1684 cm.-1, and 0.2 g. IIa. From 0.1 g. II (X = Br) stirred with 0.3 g. KOH in 8 ml. EtOH 5 min. at 100° 0.08 g. yellow II (X = OH), m. 201-1.5° (aq. EtOH), v 3260, 1701, 1647 cm.-1, was obtained. II (X = OH) with Ac2O gave orange II (X = OAc), m. 129-30°, v 1764 cm.-1 II (X = Br) (0.2 g.) with 0.4 g. KOH in 80% EtOH was refluxed 3 hrs. to give 0.14 g. III (X = OH), m. 174-5° (decompn.). II (X = Br) (0.4 g.) with 50 mg. Na in EtOH 10 min. at 78° yielded 0.3 g. orange II (X = OEt),m. 129-30°. II((X = Br) (50 mg.)in 4 ml. 27% aq. NaSH 15 min. at 100° gave 30 mg. II (X = SH), m. 222-4° (C6H6). Treatment of II (X = Br) with liquid NH3 or NaN3 gave II (X = NH2). Displacement of Br in II (X = Br) by various amines in EtOH 20 min. at 78° gave the corresponding II [X and m.p. (EtOH or aq. EtOH) given]: NHNH2, 237°; NMe2, 161-2°; NEt2, 171-2°; NHCH2CH2OH, 165-7°; N(CH2CH2OH)2, 125-6°; N(CH2CH:CH2)2, 103-4; ethylenimino, 160-1°; pyrrolidino, 194-5° (decompn.); piperidino, 103-3.5°; morpholino, 101-2°; (3-morpholinopropyl)amino, 109-10°; NHPh, 182-3°. II (X = NMe2)(0.15 g.) was refluxed in 10 ml. 60% EtOH contg. 0.3 g. KOH 3 hrs. to yield 0.1 g. III (X = NMe2), m. 167-8° (decompn.). Similarly was prepd. III (X = NEt2), m. 180° (blackens). Decarboxylations of III (X = NMe2) and III (X = NEt2) were effected in pyridine at 125-30° to give 6-dimethylaminoazulene, m. 163-4.5° (C6H6), and 6-diethylaminoazulene, m. 71-1.5° (EtOH), resp.

      Shoji, T.; Sugiyama, S.; Araki, T.; Ohta, A.; Sekiguchi, R.; Ito, S.; Mori, S.; Okujima, T.; Yasunami, M. Synthesis of 2-amino- and 2-arylazoazulenes via nucleophilic aromatic substitution of 2-chloroazulenes with amines and arylhydrazines. Org. Biomol.       16
      Synthesis of 2-amino- and 2-arylazoazulenes via nucleophilic aromatic substitution of 2-chloroazulenes with amines and arylhydrazines
      Shoji, Taku; Sugiyama, Shuhei; Araki, Takanori; Ohta, Akira; Sekiguchi, Ryuta; Ito, Shunji; Mori, Shigeki; Okujima, Tetsuo; Yasunami, Masafumi
      Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2017), 15 (18), 3917-3923CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The SNAr reaction of 2-chloroazulene deriv. with ethoxycarbonyl groups at the 1,3-positions of the azulene ring with several amines afforded the corresponding 2-aminoazulenes in excellent yields. 2-Chloroazulene without the electron-withdrawing groups reacted with highly nucleophilic cyclic amines (i.e., morpholine, piperidine and pyrrolidine) under the high-temp. conditions in a sealed tube to produce the corresponding 2-aminoazulenes in good yields. 2-Aminoazulenes without the electron-withdrawing groups were also obtained in good yields by the treatment of compds. 2-aminoazulenes with 100% H3PO4, but in the cases of the reaction of 1,3-Diethoxycarbonyl-2-n-butylaminoazulene and 1,3-Diethoxycarbonyl-2-tert-butylaminolazulene with a secondary amine function, the decompn. of the products resulted. The synthesis of 2-arylazoazulenes was also established via the SNAr reaction of 2-chloroazulene deriv. with arylhydrazines. The optical and electrochem. properties of the 2-arylazoazulene derivs. were examd. by UV/visible spectroscopy, theor. calcns. and voltammetric expts.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXmtVSgsLw%253D&md5=ecfc4c25a3f8cd542452972d04255e4c

    19. 19
      Ito, S.; Nomura, A.; Morita, N.; Kabuto, C.; Kobayashi, H.; Maejima, S.; Fujimori, K.; Yasunami, M. Synthesis and Two-Electron Redox Behavior of Diazuleno[2,1-a:1,2-c]naphthalenes. J. Org. Chem. 2002, 67, 7295– 7302,  DOI: 10.1021/jo020381u
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19
      Synthesis and two-electron redox behavior of diazuleno[2,1-a:1,2-c]naphthalenes
      Ito, Shunji; Nomura, Akiko; Morita, Noboru; Kabuto, Chizuko; Kobayashi, Hirokazu; Maejima, Seiko; Fujimori, Kunihide; Yasunami, Masafumi
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2002), 67 (21), 7295-7302CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      Diels-Alder reaction of di-2-azulenylacetylene with tetraphenylcyclopentadienone gave the tetraphenyldiazulenonaphthalene I (R = H) in one pot via autoxidn. of a presumed 1,2-di-2-azulenylbenzene deriv. In contrast, similar reaction of bis(1-methoxycarbonyl-2-azulenyl)acetylene with tetraphenylcyclopentadienone gave the 1,2-di-2-azulenylbenzene II. Cyclodehydrogenation of II with FeCl3 gave I (R = CO2Me). The redox behavior of these novel diazuleno[2,1-a:1,2-c]naphthalenes was examd. by cyclic voltammetry (CV). I exhibited two-step oxidn. waves at +0.22 to +0.71 V upon CV, which revealed the formation of a radical cation and dication stabilized by the fused two azulene rings under the electrochem. oxidn. conditions. Since the 1,2-di-2-azulenylbenzene deriv. was oxidized at higher oxidn. potentials (+0.83 and +1.86 V), the fusion of the two azulene rings to naphthalene increased electron-donating properties because of the formation of a closed-shell dicationic structure. Formation of the radical cation was characterized by UV-vis spectroscopy under the electrochem. oxidn. conditions, although no evidence was obtained for the presumed dication under the conditions of the UV-visible spectroscopy measurement.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XmvF2nu7s%253D&md5=0106edab7c780ef5cee10df6d386078b
      open URL

      Narita, M.; Murafuji, T.; Yamashita, S.; Fujinaga, M.; Hiyama, K.; Oka, Y.; Tani, F.; Kamijo, S.; Ishiguro, K. Synthesis of 2-Iodoazulenes by the Iododeboronation of Azulen-2-ylboronic Acid Pinacol Esters with Copper(I) Iodide. J. Org. Chem. 2018, 83, 1298– 1303,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.joc.7b02820

      20
      Synthesis of 2-Iodoazulenes by the Iododeboronation of Azulen-2-ylboronic Acid Pinacol Esters with Copper(I) Iodide
      Narita, Masahiro; Murafuji, Toshihiro; Yamashita, Saki; Fujinaga, Masayuki; Hiyama, Kumiko; Oka, Yurie; Tani, Fumito; Kamijo, Shin; Ishiguro, Katsuya
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2018), 83 (3), 1298-1303CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      Azulen-2-ylboronic acid pinacol ester, prepd. by iridium-catalyzed C-H borylation of azulene, efficiently underwent iododeboronation with a stoichiometric amt. of copper(I) iodide. This reaction allowed the synthesis of 2-iodoazulene in only two steps starting from azulene. This methodol. was successfully applied to analogous azulenes.

    26. 26
      Michinobu, T.; Boudon, C.; Gisselbrecht, J.-P.; Seiler, P.; Frank, B.; Moonen, N. N. P.; Gross, M.; Diederich, F. Donor-Substituted 1,1,4,4-Tetracyanobutadienes (TCBDs): New Chromophores with Efficient Intramolecular Charge-Transfer Interactions by Atom-Economic Synthesis. Chem. - Eur. J. 2006, 12, 1889– 1905,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.200501113
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      26
      Donor-substituted 1,1,4,4-Tetracyanobutadienes (TCBDs). New chromophores with efficient intramolecular charge-transfer interactions by atom-economic synthesis
      Michinobu, Tsuyoshi; Boudon, Corinne; Gisselbrecht, Jean-Paul; Seiler, Paul; Frank, Brian; Moonen, Nicolle N. P.; Gross, Maurice; Diederich, Francois
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2006), 12 (7), 1889-1905CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A wide variety of monomeric and oligomeric, donor-substituted 1,1,4,4-tetracyanobutadienes (TCBDs) have been synthesized by [2+2] cycloaddn. between tetracyanoethylene (TNCE) and donor-substituted alkynes, followed by electrocyclic ring opening of the initially formed cyclobutenes. Reaction yields are often nearly quant. but can be affected by the electron-donating power and steric demands of the alkyne substituents. The intramol. charge-transfer (CT) interactions between the donor and TCBD acceptor moieties were comprehensively investigated by X-ray crystallog., electrochem., UV-visible spectroscopy, and theor. calcns. Despite the nonplanarity of the new chromophores, which have a substantial twist between the two dicyanovinyl planes, efficient intramol. CT interactions are obsd., and the crystal structures demonstrate a high quinoid character in strong donor substituents, such as N,N-dimethylanilino (DMA) rings. The maxima of the CT bands shift bathochromically upon redn. of the amt. of conjugative coupling between strong donor and acceptor moieties. Each TCBD moiety undergoes two reversible, one-electron redn. steps. Thus, a tri-TCBD deriv. with a 1,3,5-trisubstituted benzene core shows six reversible redn. steps within an exceptionally narrow potential range of 1.0 V. The first redn. potential Ered,1 is strongly influenced by the donor substitution: introduction of more donor moieties causes an increasingly twisted TCBD structure, a fact that results in the elevation of the LUMO level and, consequently, a more difficult first redn. The potentials are also strongly influenced by the nature of the donor residues and the extent of donor-acceptor coupling. A careful comparison of electrochem. data and the correlation with UV-visible spectra made it possible to est. unknown phys. parameters such as the Ered,1 of unsubstituted TCBD (-0.31 V vs. Fc+/Fc) as well as the maxima of highly broadened CT bands. Donor-substituted TCBDs are stable mols. and can be sublimed without decompn. With their high third-order optical non-linearities, as revealed in preliminary measurements, they should become interesting chromophores for ultra-thin film formation by vapor deposition techniques and have applications in opto-electronic devices.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      (a) Ikegami, A.; Suda, M.; Watanabe, T.; Einaga, Y. Reversible Optical Manipulation of Superconductivity. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2010, 49, 372– 374,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.200904548

      (b) Chen, Y.; Li, C.; Xu, X.; Liu, M.; He, Y.; Murtaza, I.; Zhang, D.; Yao, C.; Wang, Y.; Meng, H. Thermal and Optical Modulation of the Carrier Mobility in OTFTs Based on an Azo-anthracene Liquid Crystal Organic Semiconductor. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2017, 9, 7305– 7314,  DOI: 10.1021/acsami.6b13500
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      31b
      Thermal and Optical Modulation of the Carrier Mobility in OTFTs Based on an Azo-anthracene Liquid Crystal Organic Semiconductor
      Chen, Yantong; Li, Chao; Xu, Xiuru; Liu, Ming; He, Yaowu; Murtaza, Imran; Zhang, Dongwei; Yao, Chao; Wang, Yongfeng; Meng, Hong
      ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2017), 9 (8), 7305-7314CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
      One of the most striking features of org. semiconductors compared with their corresponding inorg. counterparts is their mol. diversity. The major challenge in org. semiconductor material technol. is creating mol. structural motifs to develop multifunctional materials in order to achieve the desired functionalities yet to optimize the specific device performance. Azo-compds., because of their special photoresponsive property, have attracted extensive interest in photonic and optoelectronic applications; if incorporated wisely in the org. semiconductor groups, they can be innovatively utilized in advanced smart electronic applications, where thermal and photo modulation is applied to tune the electronic properties. On the basis of this aspiration, a novel azo-functionalized liq. crystal semiconductor material, (E)-1-(4-(anthracen-2-yl)phenyl)-2-(4-(decyloxy)phenyl)diazene (APDPD), is designed and synthesized for application in org. thin-film transistors (OTFTs). The UV-vis spectra of APDPD exhibit reversible photoisomerization upon photoexcitation, and the thin films of APDPD show a long-range orientational order based on its liq. crystal phase. The performance of OTFTs based on this material as well as the effects of thermal treatment and UV-irradn. on mobility are investigated. The mol. structure, stability of the material, and morphol. of the thin films are characterized by thermal gravimetric anal. (TGA), polarizing optical microscopy (POM), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), UV-vis spectroscopy, at. force microscopy (AFM), and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM). This study reveals that our new material has the potential to be applied in optical sensors, memories, logic circuits, and functional switches.

      open URL

      (c) Maity, D. K.; Dey, A.; Ghosh, S.; Halder, A.; Ray, P. P.; Ghoshal, D. Set of Multifunctional Azo Functionalized Semiconducting Cd(II)-MOFs Showing Photoswitching Property and Selective CO2 Adsorption. Inorg. Chem. 2018, 57, 251– 263,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.inorgchem.7b02435
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      31c
      Set of Multifunctional Azo Functionalized Semiconducting Cd(II)-MOFs Showing Photoswitching Property and Selective CO2 Adsorption
      Maity, Dilip Kumar; Dey, Arka; Ghosh, Saheli; Halder, Arijit; Ray, Partha Pratim; Ghoshal, Debajyoti
      Inorganic Chemistry (2018), 57 (1), 251-263CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Syntheses, structural characterizations, photoluminescence and adsorption properties of three new azo-functionalized Cd(II)-MOFs, namely, {[Cd(azbpy)(msuc)]·2.5(H2O)}n (2), {[Cd(azbpy)(mglu)]·5(H2O)}n (3) and {[Cd1.5(azbpy)2(glu)]·(NO3)·MeOH}n (4) [msuc = methylsuccinate; mglut = methylglutarate; glut = glutarate, azbpy = 4,4'-azobispyridine] are reported. The compds. show different structures only with the variation of aliph. dicarboxylates. The photo-switching behavior for 1-3 along with one of the authors' previously reported azo-functionalized Cd(II)-MOFs, namely, {[Cd(azbpy)(suc)]•2(H2O)}n (1) was studied extensively. At photo illuminated condition, the cond. values can draw a clear structure-property relation among the structures of compds. 1-4. Single crystal structural anal. reveals that all compds. exhibit a three-dimensional (3D) framework connected by azbpy linker and resp. aliph. dicarboxylate through bis-chelating mono/bis oxo-bridging fashion. 1-3 Exhibit an iso-structural honeycomb like 3-dimensional frameworks showing the same coordination environments; where the metal-carboxylate 2-dimensional sheets of compds. 1-3 are pillared by N,N-donor azbpy linkers. However, 4 exhibits a 2-fold interpenetrated 3-dimensional framework with a little difference in its coordination environment and the pillaring of 1-dimensional metal-carboxylate ladder by azbpy linkers. All the compds. significantly demonstrate their enhanced sensitivity under light rather than the dark condition. The gas and solvent vapor sorption studies were performed for 2-4. Also, compd. 2 exhibits an enhanced type IV selective CO2 adsorption isotherm over N2 along with the appearance of gate opening phenomena.

      32a
      Photofunctional Vesicles Containing Prussian Blue and Azobenzene
      Einaga, Y.; Sato, O.; Iyoda, T.; Fujishima, A.; Hashimoto, K.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1999), 121 (15), 3745-3750CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The intercalation of inorg. materials into organized org. assemblies presents many opportunities for the development of new functional materials with superior physicochem. properties. The authors have designed a composite material comprising Prussian blue intercalated into photoresponsive org. mols. (azobenzene-contg. multi-bilayer vesicles). Photoisomerization in the solid system was achieved by dilg. the azobenzene-contg. bilayer membrane in a poly(vinyl alc.) matrix. The photoisomerization of the film was accompanied by a geometrically confined structural change within the vesicles, as reflected by changes in the dipole moment and electrostatic field. As a result, the authors were able to control the magnetic properties of this material by photoillumination.

      (b) Fang, G.; Shi, Y.; Maclennan, J. E.; Clark, N. A.; Farrow, M. J.; Walba, D. M. Photoreversible Liquid Crystal Alignment using Azobenzene-Based Self-Assembled Monolayers: Comparison of the Bare Monolayer and Liquid Crystal Reorientation Dynamics. Langmuir 2010, 26, 17482– 17488,  DOI: 10.1021/la102788j
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32b
      Photoreversible Liquid Crystal Alignment using Azobenzene-Based Self-Assembled Monolayers: Comparison of the Bare Monolayer and Liquid Crystal Reorientation Dynamics
      Fang, Guanjiu; Shi, Yue; Maclennan, Joseph E.; Clark, Noel A.; Farrow, Matthew J.; Walba, David M.
      Langmuir (2010), 26 (22), 17482-17488CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
      Photosensitive surfaces treated to have in-plane structural anisotropy by illumination with polarized light can be used to orient liq. crystals (LCs). Here the authors report a detailed study of the dynamic behavior of this process at both short and long times, comparing the ordering induced in the bare active surface with that of the LC in contact with the surface using a high-sensitivity polarimeter that enables detailed characterization of the anisotropy of the active surface. The expts. were carried out using self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) made from dimethylaminoazobenzene covalently bonded to a glass surface through a triethoxysilane terminus. This surface gives planar alignment of the liq. crystal director with an azimuthal orientation that can be controlled by the polarization of actinic light. The authors find a remarkable long-term collective interaction between the orientationally ordered SAM and the director field of the LC: while an azobenzene based SAM in contact with an isotropic gas or liq. relaxes to an azimuthally isotropic state in the absence of light due to thermal fluctuations, an orientationally written SAM in contact with LC in the absence of light can maintain the LC director twist permanently, i.e., the SAM is capable of providing azimuthal anchoring to the LC even in the presence of a torque about the surface normal. The authors find that the short-time, transient LC reorientation is limited by the weak azimuthal anchoring strength of the SAM and by the LC viscosity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

An Azo-Bridged Ferroelectric Liquid Crystal with Highly Enhanced Second and Third Harmonic Generation. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 16298– 16306,  DOI: 10.1021/ja3062826

      (d) Shi, Y.; Fang, G.; Glaser, M. A.; Maclennan, J. E.; Korblova, E.; Walba, D. M.; Clark, N. A. Phase Winding of a Nematic Liquid Crystal by Dynamic Localized Reorientation of an Azo-Based Self-Assembled Monolayer. Langmuir 2014, 30, 9560– 9566,  DOI: 10.1021/la501983u
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32d
      Phase Winding of a Nematic Liquid Crystal by Dynamic Localized Reorientation of an Azo-Based Self-Assembled Monolayer
      Shi, Yue; Fang, Guanjiu; Glaser, Matthew A.; Maclennan, Joseph E.; Korblova, Eva; Walba, David M.; Clark, Noel A.
      Langmuir (2014), 30 (31), 9560-9566CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
      Azobenzene-based mols. forming a self-assembled monolayer (SAM) tethered to a glass surface are highly photosensitive and readily reorient liq. crystals in contact with them when illuminated with polarized actinic light. The authors probe the coupling of such monolayers to nematic liq. crystal in a hybrid cell by studying the dynamics of liq. crystal reorientation in response to local orientational changes of the monolayer induced by a focused actinic laser with a rotating polarization. The steady increase in the azimuth of the mean mol. orientation of the SAM around the laser beam locally reorients the nematic, winding up an extended set of nested rings of splay-bend nematic director reorientation until the cumulative elastic torque exceeds that of the surface coupling within the beam, after which the nematic director starts to slip. Quant. analyses of the ring dynamics allow measurements of the anchoring strength of the azo-SAM and its interaction with the nematic liq. crystal.

      open URL

      (e) Cha, Y. J.; Gim, M.-J.; Ahn, H.; Shin, T. J.; Jeong, J.; Yoon, D. K. Orthogonal Liquid Crystal Alignment Layer: Templating Speed-Dependent Orientation of Chromonic Liquid Crystals. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2017, 9, 18355– 18361,  DOI: 10.1021/acsami.7b04188
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32e
      Orthogonal Liquid Crystal Alignment Layer: Templating Speed-Dependent Orientation of Chromonic Liquid Crystals
      Cha, Yun Jeong; Gim, Min-Jun; Ahn, Hyungju; Shin, Tae Joo; Jeong, Joonwoo; Yoon, Dong Ki
      ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2017), 9 (21), 18355-18361CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
      Lyotropic chromonic liq. crystals (LCLCs) have been extensively studied because of the interesting structural characteristics of the linear aggregation of their plank-shaped mols. in aq. solvents. We report a simple method to control the orientation of LCLCs such as Sunset Yellow (SSY), disodium cromoglycate (DSCG), and DNA by varying pulling speed of the top substrate and temps. during shear flow induced expt. Crystd. columns of LCLCs are aligned parallel and perpendicular to the shear direction, at fast and slow pulling speeds of the top substrate, resp. On the basis of this result, we fabricated an orthogonally patterned film that can be used as an alignment layer for guiding rodlike liq. crystals (LCs) to generate both twisted and planar alignments simultaneously. Our resulting platform can provide a facile method to form multidirectional orientation of soft materials and biomaterials in a process of simple shearing and evapn., which gives rise to potential patterning applications using LCLCs due to their unique structural characteristics.

      (a) Wang, D.; Wang, X. Self-Assembled Graphene/Azo Polyelectrolyte Multilayer Film and Its Application in Electrochemical Energy Storage Device. Langmuir 2011, 27, 2007– 2013,  DOI: 10.1021/la1044128
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      34a
      Self-assembled graphene/azo polyelectrolyte multilayer film and its application in electrochemical energy storage device
      Wang, Dongrui; Wang, Xiaogong
      Langmuir (2011), 27 (5), 2007-2013CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
      Graphene/azo polyelectrolyte multilayer films were fabricated through electrostatic layer-by-layer (LbL) self-assembly, and their performance as electrochem. capacitor electrode was investigated. Cationic azo polyelectrolyte (QP4VP-co-PCN) was synthesized through radical polymn., postpolymn. azo coupling reaction, and quaternization. Neg. charged graphene nanosheets were prepd. by a chem. modified method. The LbL films were obtained by alternately dipping a piece of the pretreated substrates in the QP4VP-co-PCN and nanosheet solns. The processes were repeated until the films with required nos. of bilayers were obtained. The self-assembly and multilayer surface morphol. were characterized by UV-vis spectroscopy, AFM, SEM, and TEM. The performance of the LbL films as electrochem. capacitor electrode was estd. using cyclic voltammetry. Results show that the graphene nanosheets are densely packed in the multilayers and form random graphene network. The azo polyelectrolyte cohesively interacts with the nanosheets in the multilayer structure, which prevents agglomeration of graphene nanosheets. The sheet resistance of the LbL films decreases with the increase of the layer nos. and reaches the stationary value of 1.0 × 106 Ω/ for the film with 15 bilayers. At a scanning rate of 50 mV/s, the LbL film with 9 bilayers shows a gravimetric specific capacitance of 49 F/g in 1.0 M Na2SO4 soln. The LbL films developed in this work could be a promising type of the electrode materials for elec. energy storage devices.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      34b
      Copper(I)-Catalyzed Synthesis of Nanoporous Azo-Linked Polymers: Impact of Textural Properties on Gas Storage and Selective Carbon Dioxide Capture
      Arab, Pezhman; Rabbani, Mohammad Gulam; Sekizkardes, Ali Kemal; Islamoglu, Timur; El-Kaderi, Hani M.
      Chemistry of Materials (2014), 26 (3), 1385-1392CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      A new facile method for synthesis of porous azo-linked polymers (ALPs) is reported. The synthesis of ALPs was accomplished by homocoupling of aniline-like building units in the presence of copper-(I) bromide and pyridine. The resulting ALPs exhibit high surface areas (SABET = 862-1235 m2 g-1), high physiochem. stability, and considerable gas storage capacity esp. at high-pressure settings. Under low pressure conditions, ALPs have remarkable CO2 uptake (up to 5.37 mmol g-1 at 273 K and 1 bar), as well as moderate CO2/N2 (29-43) and CO2/CH4 (6-8) selectivity. Low pressure gas uptake expts. were used to calc. the binding affinities of small gas mols. and revealed that ALPs have high heats of adsorption for hydrogen (7.5-8 kJ mol-1), methane (18-21 kJ mol-1), and carbon dioxide (28-30 kJ mol-1). Under high pressure conditions, the best performing polymer, ALP-1, stores significant amts. of H2 (24 g L-1, 77 K/70 bar), CH4 (67 g L-1, 298 K/70 bar), and CO2 (304 g L-1, 298 K/40 bar).

      Photoliquefiable Ionic Crystals: A Phase Crossover Approach for Photon Energy Storage Materials with Functional Multiplicity
      Ishiba, Keita; Morikawa, Masa-aki; Chikara, Chie; Yamada, Teppei; Iwase, Katsunori; Kawakita, Mika; Kimizuka, Nobuo
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2015), 54 (5), 1532-1536CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Ionic crystals (ICs) of the azobenzene derivs. show photoinduced IC-ionic liq. (IL) phase transition (photoliquefaction) upon UV-irradn., and the resulting cis-azobenzene ILs are reversibly photocrystd. by illumination with visible light. The photoliquefaction of ICs is accompanied by a significant increase in ionic cond. at ambient temp. The photoliquefaction also brings the azobenzene ICs further significance as photon energy storage materials. The cis-IL shows thermally induced crystn. to the trans-IC phase. This transition is accompanied by exothermic peaks with a total ΔH of 97.1 kJ mol-1, which is almost double the conformational energy stored in cis-azobenzene chromophores. Thus, the integration of photoresponsive ILs and self-assembly pushes the limit of solar thermal batteries.

      34d
      Target Synthesis of an Azo (N=N) Based Covalent Organic Framework with High CO2-over-N2 Selectivity and Benign Gas Storage Capability
      Ge, Rile; Hao, Dandan; Shi, Qi; Dong, Bin; Leng, Wenguang; Wang, Chang; Gao, Yanan
      Journal of Chemical & Engineering Data (2016), 61 (5), 1904-1909CODEN: JCEAAX; ISSN:0021-9568. (American Chemical Society)
      An azo (N=N) based covalent org. framework (COF-TpAzo) was synthesized via a Schiff base condensation reaction. The Braunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) sp. surface area up to 1552 m2·g-1 was obtained for the framework with a pore vol. of 0.97 cm3·g-1. The COF-TpAzo exhibits a high selectivity in CO2/N2 (127/145 at 273/298 K, resp., Henry method) due to the N2-phobic and CO2-philic feature of COF-TpAzo. Furthermore, hydrogen and methane storage capacities of the nitrogen-rich COF-TpAzo were investigated. The COF-TpAzo shows high H2 and CH4 storage capacity at 1 bar (10.6 mg·g-1 at 77 K for H2, 11.2 mg·g-1 at 273 K for CH4, and 5.5 mg·g-1 at 298 K for CH4).
